Sec. 2-136. - Generally. (a) Composition. The police department shall consist of the chief of police and such other officers and personnel as the mayor and council shall prescribe. (b) Rank. Following the police chief in rank shall be the captain, the lieutenants, sergeants, and the policemen, in order of seniority in each group. (c) Police chief: (1) Appointment and powers. The police chief shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council, and shall be the chief executive officer of the police department, subject always to the orders and regulations of the mayor and council. In the exercise of his duties, the police chief shall have the power to establish and enforce rules and regulations for the government of the members and employees of the department, which rules shall, however, be consistent with the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state. (2) Duties. The police chief shall have the following duties: a. To attend all meetings of the city council and all trials before the recorder's court; b. To see to the proper service of all summonses, subpoenas, citations, executions, attachments and rules of the city council; c. To see to the collection of all fines and costs imposed by the recorder's court; d. To see that the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city and all statutes applicable therein are faithfully enforced; e. To preserve the public peace, prevent infractions of the law and arrest any violators thereof; f. To protect the rights of persons and property; g. To oversee the conduct of the officers and men of the police force, and to be held strictly responsible for such conduct and for the general good order of the department; h. To keep adequate records of all personnel and equipment of the department, including a log of all questions, activities and investigations; i. To submit a monthly report to the city council outlining the number and type of arrests for state offenses, the number and type of cases involving violations of municipal ordinances, and the number of arrests made and cases reported by each police officer; j. To submit monthly to the state department of public safety the Uniform Crime Report prescribed by state law; and k. To discharge such other duties as may be required of him by the mayor or council. (3) Resignation, removal, death or disability. In the event of resignation, removal, death or disability of the police chief, the officer next in rank shall perform the duties of the chief until removal of such disability or until a successor has been duly appointed. (d) Police officers: (1) Qualifications. Any person employed by the city as a police officer shall have the following qualifications: a. Be at least eighteen (18) years of age; b. Be a citizen of the United States; c. Have a high school diploma or its recognized equivalent; d. Not have been convicted, by any state or by the federal government, of any crime, the punishment for which could have been imprisonment in a federal or state prison or institution; nor shall he have been convicted of sufficient misdemeanors to establish a pattern of disregard for the law; e. Be fingerprinted and a search made of local, state, and national fingerprint files to disclose any criminal record; f. Possess good moral character as determined by investigation under procedures established by the state peace officers standards and training council; g. Have an oral interview with the mayor and city council to determine such things as the applicant's appearance, background and ability to communicate; h. Be found, after examination by a licensed physician or surgeon, to be free from any physical, emotional or mental conditions which might adversely affect his exercising the powers or duties of a police officer; and i. Complete satisfactorily at least a basic course of two hundred forty (240) hours of instruction within twelve (12) months of the date of his appointment as a police officer, except that an extension may be granted by the state peace officers standards and training council on account of illness, injury, military service or other reasons deemed sufficient by that council. (2) Duties. It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to acquire a full knowledge of and to enforce all of the ordinances of the city and all statutes applicable therein, to become familiar with the rules and regulations established by the police chief concerning the discipline, good order, proper conduct, care and management of the police department, and to respect and obey all orders of the police chief not in conflict with the law or ordinances of the city. (3) Conduct. Every member of the police department shall conduct himself in a proper and law-abiding manner at all times and shall avoid the use of unnecessary force. Prohibited conduct shall include, but not be limited to, the following: a. Absence from regular hours of duty without permission; b. Sleeping on duty; c. Insubordination or disobedience of orders; d. Drinking any malt or intoxicating beverage while on duty or in uniform; e. Wilful maltreatment of any person or prisoner; f. Using profane language; g. Giving out or releasing any information covering the affairs, business or operation of the police department without the consent of the police chief; h. Receiving or accepting a reward from any person for any services rendered in the line of duty; i. Accepting bribes of money, gifts or other articles of apparent or actual value, or accepting any fee, reward or gift of any kind from a person arrested or from any friend in his behalf while he is in custody or after his release or discharge; or j. Active participation in any political campaign to the neglect of his official duty. (4) Penalties for improper conduct. Any police officer violating the rules or regulations of the police department or of this Code, upon conviction therefor by the city council, after due notice and hearing, or upon the plea of guilty, shall be reprimanded, fined, suspended or dismissed by the city council. Any one (1) or more of these penalties may be imposed in the discretion of the city council. (e) Arms and uniforms. Each officer and member of the police department shall be furnished with such uniforms, arms and police equipment as provided for by the city council. Uniforms shall be kept clean and pressed and shall be worn on duty at all times, unless otherwise ordered by a superior officer. The equipment, arms and uniforms furnished by the city shall be and always remain the property of the city and shall be, when a change is ordered or on retirement from office, returned to the city. The members of the department shall be liable for any loss or careless destruction of or damage to their arms and uniforms. (f) Arrests. Police officers of the city may make arrests for violations of municipal ordinances and state laws when such violations are committed in their presence or when they have obtained a valid arrest warrant from the judge of the city court or from some other proper authority. In exercising such power of arrest, all police officers shall see that all necessary warnings are given to the accused as required by law. (g) Entering private dwellings. No police officer shall enter a private dwelling without a search or arrest warrant unless he is in pursuit of a fugitive who the officer has personal knowledge or probable cause to believe has committed or attempted to commit a felony. (h) Disposition of stolen, abandoned, or impounded property: (1) All personal property which comes into the custody of the police department, where the property has been stolen or impounded or where the ownership is unknown, shall be held for a period of forty-five (45) days awaiting claim by its owner. The owner of the property, upon proving ownership and paying all expenses and costs, including reasonable charges for storage, shall have the right to have such property returned to him. (2) If after the expiration of forty-five (45) days the property is unclaimed, the chief of police shall advertise the property for sale in the newspaper in which the city's legal advertisements are printed. Such advertising shall take place at least seven (7) days before the date set for the sale and shall give a description of the property to be sold and specify the time and place of sale. If the property is still unclaimed by the time of the sale, it shall be sold as advertised and the proceeds shall be placed in the city treasury. DIVISION 4. - SOUTH FULTON MUNICIPAL REGIONAL JAIL DEPARTMENT
Sec. 2-150. - Generally. (a) Composition. The jail shall consist of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief and such other officers and personnel as the mayor and council shall prescribe. (b) Rank. Following the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief in rank shall be the assistant chief. (c) South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief. (1) Appointment and powers. The South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council, and shall be the chief executive officer of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail, subject always to the orders and regulations of the mayor and council. In the exercise of his duties, the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief shall have the powers to establish and enforce rules and regulations for the government of the members and employees of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department, which rules shall, however, be consistent with the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state. (2) Duties. The South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief shall have the following duties: a. To attend all meetings of the city council and South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Authority; b. To establish necessary rules and regulations concerning conduct, care, and management of the department and inmates, subject to the approval of the mayor and council; c. To oversee the conduct of the jailers and other employees of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department, and to be held strictly responsible for such conduct and for the general good of the department; d. To keep adequate records of all personnel, equipment, and inmates in the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department, including incident reports of all questions, activities, and investigations; and e. To discharge such other duties as may be required of him by the mayor and council. (3) Resignation, removal, death or disability. In the event of resignation, removal, death or disability of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief, the employee next in rank in the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall perform the duties of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief until removal of said chief's disability or until a successor has been duly appointed by the mayor and council. (d) Jailers. (1) Qualifications. Any person employed by the city as a jailer shall have the following qualifications: a. Be at least eighteen (18) years of age; b. Be a citizen of the United States; c. Have a high school diploma or its recognized equivalent; d. Not have been convicted, by any state or by the federal government, of any felony; nor shall he have been convicted of any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; e. Be fingerprinted and a search made of local, state, and national fingerprint files to disclose any criminal record; f. Possess good moral character as determined by investigation under procedures established by the Georgia Peace Officers Standards and Training Council (POST); g. Be found, after examination by a licensed physician or surgeon, to be free from any physical, emotional or mental conditions which might adversely affect his exercise of power or commission of his/her duties as a jailer; and h. Complete satisfactorily at least a basic training course of eighty (80) hours of instruction within six (6) months of the date of his appointment as a jailer. (2) Duties. It shall be the duty of a jailer of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail to acquire a full knowledge of, observe, and to enforce the rules and regulations established by the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief, or any other appropriate federal, state, or city authority concerning the good order, proper conduct, care and management of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail; and to acquire full knowledge of, observe and enforce the rules and regulations established by the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief or any other appropriate federal, state, or city authority governing the interactions of staff and inmates including, but not limited to, limits on the use of force, physical or verbal contact with current and former inmates, and the proper handling of inmates and the property thereof; and to respect and obey all orders of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief not in conflict with the law or ordinances of the city. (3) Conduct. Every member of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall conduct himself in a proper and law-abiding manner at all times and shall not use unnecessary force. Prohibited conduct shall include, but not be limited to, the following: a. Absence from regular hours of duty without permission; b. Sleeping on duty; c. Insubordination; d. Drinking any malt or intoxicating beverage while on duty or in uniform; e. Willful maltreatment of any person or inmate; f. Using profane language; g. Giving out or releasing any information covering the affairs, business or operation of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department without the consent of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief; h. Receiving or accepting a reward from any person for any services rendered in the line of duty; i. Accepting bribes of money, gifts or other articles of apparent or actual value, or accepting any fee, reward or gift of any kind from a person held at the jail of from any friend on an inmate's behalf while he/she is in custody or after his/her release or discharge; or j. Active participation in any political campaign to the neglect of his official duty. (e) Arms and uniforms. Each jailer and member of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Department shall be furnished with such uniforms, arms and equipment as specified by the jail chief. Uniforms shall be kept clean and pressed and shall be worn on duty at all times, unless otherwise ordered by a superior. The equipment, arms and uniforms furnished by the city shall be and always will remain the property of the city and shall be returned to the city upon demand, termination of the jailer, retirement of the jailer, a change of equipment or uniform, or similar event. (f) [Duty regarding familiarity with equipment and apparatus.] Each jailer and member of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall have a duty to become familiar with and proficient in handling all jail equipment and apparatus necessary to the discharge of his/her duties, including any arms and/or uniforms. (g) Disposition of stolen, abandoned, or impounded property. (1) All personal property which comes into the custody of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall be securely held by the department and released into the custody of the prisoner whom owns the property or to a person designated in writing by said prisoner upon the release of said prisoner. If property exists whose owner is unknown or cannot be located, it shall be securely held for a period of ninety (90) days awaiting claim by its owner. The owner of the property, upon proving ownership and paying any expenses and costs, including reasonable charges for storage, shall have the right to have such property returned to him. (2) If after the expiration of ninety (90) days the property is unclaimed, the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall forward the property to the police chief. The police chief shall advertise the property for sale in the newspaper in which the City's legal advertisements are printed. Such advertising shall take place at least seven (7) days before the date set out for the sale and shall give a description of the property to be sold and specify the time and place of sale. If the property is still unclaimed by the time of the sale, it shall be sold as advertised and the proceeds shall be placed in the city treasury. (Ord.
