Sec. 2-201. - Law enforcement alliance. City of Union City agrees to aid and assist other municipalities and counties adopting an ordinance identical hereto in its substantive provisions and approved by Union City Chief of Police, in such law enforcement investigations and activities as may be authorized pursuant to procedures herein set forth. Investigations and activities so authorized shall entail to the participating municipalities and counties the respective rights, status and obligations herein defined, as fully as if set forth by contract. (Ord. No. 89-21, § 1, 10-3-89) Sec. 2-202. - Assistance request. Requests for assistance shall be initiated by the chief of police or other chief law enforcement officer of the requesting municipality or county to the chief of police or other chief enforcement officer of each municipality or county whose assistance is requested, accompanied by oral or written statement of his enforcement objective. Such statement shall include at a minimum, the purpose, proposed duration; manpower and equipment requirements; name and employing entity of the officer in charge of such investigation or activity; insofar as practicable, the names of persons and officers reasonably expected to participate and the nature of assistance requested. Such investigation and/or activity shall be conclusively presumed to be authorized by the municipality or county employing the requesting officer. (Ord. No. 89-21, § 2, 10-3-89) Sec. 2-203. - Response to request. The chief of police or other chief law enforcement officer of the municipality or county receiving such request for assistance shall honor or decline such request promptly on receipt and shall not unreasonably decline to assist. (Ord. No. 89-21, § 3, 10-3-89) Sec. 2-204. - Manner of assistance. Requests may be honored for manpower or equipment. Officers detailed responsive to a request shall be deemed attached for command purposes to the chief of police or other chief law enforcement officer of the requesting municipality or county solely for the projected duration of the investigation or activity as set forth in the requesting municipality's or county's statement of the enforcement objective, unless extended by consent of the requesting municipality or county and the assisting municipality or county through their respective chiefs of police or chief law enforcement officers. (a) Qualifications and powers of officers detailed and attached. Officers detailed by an assisting municipality or county shall be certified pursuant to the Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Act; grade and experience requested; prior to commencing duties pursuant to the detail and attachment; shall be sworn as law enforcement officers of the requesting municipality or county and shall be vested while attached with the same powers, duties and authority as the requesting municipality's or county's permanent law enforcement officers. (b) Equipment loans. Detail of an officer by an assisting municipality or county shall imply authority to such officer to use while attached elsewhere, such clothing, firearms, and other equipment assigned to and normally used by such officer during duty with the assisting municipality or county. Other specific items of equipment may be loaned by an assisting municipality or county pursuant to a request, subject to the following requirements and conditions: (1) Concurrently, an officer of the assisting municipality or county who will be capable of operating or safeguarding and accounting for such equipment, shall be attached to the requesting municipality or county; (2) The chief of police or other law enforcement officer of the requesting municipality or county shall receive a receipt for such equipment when it enters his jurisdiction; (3) The requesting municipality or county shall, promptly on request, return such equipment in as good condition, normal wear and tear alone except, as when received; and (4) Equipment loaned pursuant hereto and lost, destroyed, or damaged, shall be promptly replaced or repaired at the requesting municipality's or county's expense. (Ord. No. 89-21, § 4, 10-3-89) Sec. 2-205. - Ad hoc withdrawal. Nothing herein shall prohibit unilateral withdrawal of men or equipment at any time by an assisting municipality or county, but withdrawal shall be made with full regard and due care for the integrity of the investigation or activity underway; in no event shall withdrawal occur with the initial projected duration of an assisted investigation, except by reason of compelling necessity within the assisting municipality or county. (Ord. No. 89-21, § 5, 10-3-89) Sec. 2-206. - Liability. Notwithstanding detail of an officer from an assisting municipality or county, and his attachment to a requesting municipality or county, ultimate authority over such officer and responsibility for such officer's acts, omissions and negligence shall remain with the municipality or county employing such officer. Each municipality or county assisting another pursuant to this article shall save and hold the requesting municipality or county harmless and indemnify such municipality or county as against all loss, liability and expense arising solely and proximately from acts, omissions and negligence of such officer while engaged in an assisted investigation or activity authorized pursuant hereto. It is provided, however, that nothing herein shall bar or hinder assertion by the assisting municipality or county of any defenses, counter-claims or cross-claims consistent with provisions of this article, including without limitation, the defenses of denial or liability in whole or in part, assertion of liability of another in whole or in part, and the assertion of the doctrines of accident, respondent superior, non-agency and comparative negligence. The requesting municipality or county assumes full responsibility for the use, operation, safekeeping of equipment loaned by a municipality or county pursuant to request as herein provided, for and during the period requested, or retained after expiration of such period, and shall save and hold the assisting municipality or county harmless as against loss, liability and expense arising out of use, operation or possession of such equipment by the requesting municipality or county or by an officer attached to the requesting municipality, or county as herein provided, except while used, operated or possessed by an officer employed by the assisting municipality or county. (Ord. No. 89-21, § 6, 10-3-89) Sec. 2-207. - Participating municipality defined. A "participating municipality or county" as contemplated herein shall be deemed to mean such Georgia municipality or county within a fifty-mile radius of the City of Union City as whose governing authority shall at anytime hereafter while this ordinance is of force and effect, adopt an ordinance identical hereto in its substantive provisions, and approved by the Union City Chief of Police. (Ord. No. 89-21, § 7, 10-3-89) Sec. 2-208. - Termination; effect of termination. A participating municipality or county may terminate its participation hereunder at any time by repeal of its ordinance qualifying it for such participation. Such repeal and termination, however, shall not affect its obligations arising during and out of its prior participation hereunder, either contractual or otherwise. (Ord. No. 89-21, § 8, 10-3-89) Secs. 2-209—2-220. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - BOARD, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-221—2-240. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - UNION CITY PARKS AND RECREATION COMMITTEE[13]
Footnotes: --- (13) --- Editor's note— Ordinance No. 92-6, enacted March 3, 1992, added provisions designated as a new Ch. 16 to the Code. For purposes of classification, such provisions have been redesignated as Ch. 2, Art. VII, Div. 2, §§ 2-241—2-244 at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 2-241. - Created. In order to make recommendations to the Mayor and Council as to the formulation, funding, and supervision of recreational programs and opportunities for citizens of all age groups, including senior citizens, handicapped citizens, and underprivileged youths, the Union City Parks and Recreation Committee, hereinafter referred to as the "Recreation Committee" or "committee", is hereby created and established. The Recreation Committee shall be organized and empowered as set out in this chapter. (Ord. No. 92-6, § 1, 3-3-92) Sec. 2-242. - Organization. (a) Membership. The recreation committee shall consist of five (5) members, who shall be residents of the city appointed by the mayor and council of the city. (b) Terms. The terms of the members shall be for two (2) years, except that in the appointment of the first recreation committee under the terms of this section, two (2) members shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year, and three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. The terms of all members shall begin on the first day of the month following the month in which the committee is activated. All members of the committee shall, if necessary, hold over until their successors are appointed and qualified. The successors shall be appointed in the same manner as the initial members in the month immediately preceding the expiration of the members' respective terms of office. Any member of the committee may be re-selected and re-appointed to serve a succeeding term. (c) Vacancies. A vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and council of the city. The mayor and council shall also have the power to remove any member of the committee if that member is found to be unsatisfactory in fulfilling the purpose of the committee or in performing his/her duties. (d) Compensation. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties if such expenses are approved by the city administrator. (e) Quorum. Three (3) members of the committee shall constitute a quorum. A vacancy on the committee shall not impair the right of the quorum to exercise all the rights and perform all the duties of the committee. (Ord. No. 92-6, § 2, 3-3-92) Sec. 2-243. - Election of chairperson; bylaws; miscellaneous. The recreation committee shall elect a chairperson from among its members. The term of the chairperson shall be for one (1) year with eligibility for re-election. The committee shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the municipality. The committee shall devise its own bylaws, which shall be supplied to the city administrator. The committee shall report directly to the city administrator. Any incidental expenditures of the committee shall be within the amounts appropriated for such purpose by the mayor and council of the city. (Ord. No. 92-6, § 3, 3-3-92) Sec. 2-244. - Purpose. The recreation committee is created strictly for the purpose of making recommendations on various recreation programs and activities to the mayor and council, and to advise the city administrator of various recreational issues. This chapter in no way is to be construed as creating a recreation authority. (Ord. No. 92-6, § 4, 3-3-92) Secs. 2-245—2-259. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT
Sec. 2-260. - Regulations continued in effect. All ordinances, resolutions, motions and orders pertaining to civil defense, emergency management and disaster relief, which are not in conflict with this article, are continued in full force and effect. Such ordinances, etc., are on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) Sec. 2-261. - Emergency management and response powers. (a) Declaration of local emergency. (1) Grant of authority. In the event of an actual or threatened occurrence of a disaster or emergency, which may result in the large-scale loss of life, injury, property damage or destruction or in the major disruption of routine community affairs, business or governmental operations in the city and which is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by federal, state and local departments and agencies to supplement the efforts of available public and private resources, the mayor may declare a local emergency for the City of Union City. The form of the declaration shall be similar to that provided in subsection (b) of this Code section. (2) Request for state assistance. Consistent with a declaration of local emergency, the mayor may request the governor to provide assistance, provided that the disaster or emergency is beyond the capacity of the city to meet adequately and state assistance is necessary to supplement local efforts to save lives and protect property, public health and safety, or to avert or lessen the threat of a disaster. (3) Continuance. The declaration of local emergency shall continue until the mayor finds that emergency conditions no longer exist, at which time, the mayor shall execute and file with the city clerk a document marking the end of the state of emergency. No state of local emergency shall continue for longer than thirty (30) days, unless renewed by the mayor. The city governing authority may, by resolution and in accordance with the city charter, end a state of local emergency at any time. (4) Effect of declaration of local emergency. a. Activation of emergency operations plan. A declaration of emergency by the governor or a declaration of local emergency by the mayor shall automatically activate the local emergency operations plan and shall be authority for the deployment of personnel and use of any forces to which the plan applies and for use or distribution of any supplies, equipment, materials, and facilities assembled, stockpiled or arranged to be made available pursuant to the Georgia Emergency Management Act or any other laws applicable to emergencies or disasters. 1. The fire chief and/or his/her designees shall have the legal authority to exercise the powers and discharge the duties conferred by law, including the implementation of the applicable local emergency operations plan, coordination of the emergency responses of public and private agencies and organizations, coordination of recovery efforts with county, state and federal officials, and inspection of emergency or disaster sites. 2. In responding to the emergency and conducting necessary and appropriate survey of the damages caused by the emergency, the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) or his/her designee is authorized to enter at a reasonable time upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of evaluating sites involved with emergency management functions to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 3. The fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) is authorized to execute a right of entry and/or agreement to use property for these purposes on behalf of the city; however, any such document shall be later presented for ratification by the city governing authority. 4. No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the city who requests entry for purposes of evaluating sites involved with emergency management functions to protect the health, safety, or welfare of the public, and who presents appropriate credentials. Nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while that individual is in the process of carrying out his or her official duties. b. Emergency powers. Following a declaration of emergency and during the continuance of such state of emergency, the mayor is authorized to implement local emergency measures to protect life and property or to bring the emergency situation under control. In exercising this authority, the mayor may cause to become effective any of the sections of this chapter as appropriate. If any of these sections is included in a declaration of local emergency, the same shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be in effect until the declaration of local emergency has terminated. c. Authority to waive procedures and fees. Pursuant to a declaration of emergency, the city governing authority is authorized to cause to be effective any of the subsections of section 2-263 of this chapter as appropriate. The implementation of such subsections shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. d. Additional emergency powers. The fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) shall have and may exercise for such period as the declared emergency exists or continues, the following additional emergency powers: 1. To direct and compel the evacuation of all or part of the population from any stricken or threatened area, for the preservation of life or other disaster mitigation, response or recovery; 2. To prescribe routes, modes of transportation and destinations in connection with evacuation; 3. To make provision for the availability and use of temporary emergency housing, emergency shelters and/or emergency medical shelters; 4. To transfer the direction, personnel or functions of any city departments and agencies or units thereof for the purpose of performing or facilitating emergency services; 5. To utilize all available resources of the city and subordinate agencies over which the city has budgetary control as reasonably necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster; 6. To utilize public property when necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster or when there is compelling necessity for the protection of lives, health and welfare; and/or the property of citizens; 7. To suspend any law, code provision or regulation prescribing the procedures for conduct of city business, or the orders, rules or regulations of any city agency, if strict compliance with any ordinance, resolution, order, rule or regulation would in any way prevent, hinder or delay necessary action in coping with the emergency or disaster, provided that such suspension shall provide for the minimum deviation from the requirements under the circumstances and further provided that, when practicable, specialists shall be assigned to avoid adverse effects resulting from such suspension; 8. To provide benefits to citizens upon execution of an intergovernmental agreement for grants to meet disaster-related necessary expenses or serious needs of individuals or families adversely affected by an emergency or disaster in cases where the individuals or families are unable to meet the expenses or needs from other means, provided that such grants are authorized only when matching state or federal funds are available for such purposes; 9. To perform and exercise such other functions, powers and duties as may be deemed necessary to promote and secure the safety and protection of the civilian population, including individuals with household pets and service animals prior to, during, and following a major disaster or emergency. (b) Form of declaration. Upon the declaration of local emergency, an official "Declaration of Local Emergency," in substantially the same form set forth below, shall be signed and filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be communicated to the citizens of the affected area using the most effective and efficient means available. The declaration shall state the nature of the emergency or disaster, the conditions that require the declaration and any sections of this chapter which shall be in effect. "DECLARATION OF LOCAL EMERGENCY WHEREAS, the City of Union City, Georgia has experienced an event of critical significance as a result of [DESCRIPTION OF EVENT] on [DATE]; and WHEREAS, in the judgment of the Mayor of the City of Union City, there exist emergency circumstances located in [DESCRIBE GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION] requiring extraordinary and immediate corrective actions for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City of Union City, including individuals with household pets and service animals; and WHEREAS, to prevent or minimize injury to people and damage to property resulting from this event; NOW, THEREFORE, pursuant to the authority vested in me by local and state law; IT IS HEREBY DECLARED that a local state of emergency exists and shall continue until the conditions requiring this declaration are abated. WHEREFORE, IT IS ORDERED: (1) That the applicable local emergency operations plan is hereby activated; (2) That the following sections of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Union City be implemented: [If deemed appropriate, choose from the following: Section _____-5, Overcharging; Section _____-6, Registration of Building and Repair Services; Section _____-7, Closed or Restricted Areas and Curfews]; and (3) That the following measures also be implemented: [If deemed appropriate, select items from Section _____-2(a)(4)c, d or such other measures as appropriate.] ENTERED at [TIME] on [DATE]. [Signed] Mayor, City of ___________." (c) Contracts with local governments. In addition to the normal agreements embodied in the applicable local emergency operations plan for mutual emergency assistance, the city may contract with any municipality or county for the administration of a local emergency response program. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) Sec. 2-262. - Enforcement and remedies. (a) Law enforcement. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-4, the city police department shall be authorized to enforce the orders, rules and regulations contained in this chapter and/or implemented by the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) or local governing authority during a declared emergency. (b) Penalties. Failure to comply with any of the requirements or provisions of the regulations contained in this chapter, or with any code section, order, rule or regulation made effective by the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) or local governing authority upon or after the declaration of an emergency shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this chapter. Any person who violates any provision in this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), imprisonment for a term not exceeding one hundred eighty (180) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, for each violation. Each person assisting in the commission of a violation, shall be guilty of separate offenses. Each day during which a violation or failure to comply continues shall constitute a separate violation. (c) Injunctive relief. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-5, in addition to the remedies prescribed in this section, the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) is authorized to obtain an injunction to restrain violation of laws, code sections, orders, rules and regulations which are contained in the Georgia Emergency Management Act and/or this Code, and/or which are implemented by the local governing authority during a declared emergency. (d) Enforcement. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, this article may be enforced by the city police department. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) Sec. 2-263. - Authority to waive procedures and fee structures. (a) City business. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the affairs and business of the city may be conducted at places other than the regular or usual location, within or outside of the city, when it is not prudent, expedient or possible to conduct business at the regular location. When such meetings occur outside of the city, all actions taken by the city governing authority shall be as valid and binding as if performed within the city. Such meetings may be called by the presiding officer or any two (2) members of the governing body without regard to or compliance with time-consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by law. (b) Public works contracts. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the city may contract for public works without letting such contract out to the lowest, responsible bidder and without advertising and posting notification of such contract for four (4) weeks; provided, however, that the emergency must be of such nature that immediate action is required and that the action is necessary for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. Any public works contract entered into pursuant to this subsection shall be entered on the minutes of the city as soon as practical and the nature of the emergency described therein in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-91-22(e). Any E-Verify affidavit or other state required affidavit shall be obtained from any contractor if otherwise required by law. (c) Purchasing. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the purchasing ordinances, regulations or policies may be suspended. City officials shall continue to seek to obtain the best prices during the state of local emergency. (d) Code enforcement. Upon declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or the mayor, the city governing authority may temporarily suspend the enforcement of the ordinances of the city, or any portion thereof, where the emergency is of such nature that immediate action outside the code is required, such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety and welfare, and such suspension is not inconsistent with any federal or state statutes or regulations. (e) Fees. Upon declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or the mayor, the city may temporarily reduce or suspend any permit fees, application fees or other rate structures as necessary to encourage the rebuilding of the areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" include fees or rates charged by the city for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits and other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair and clean up of areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" does not include fees collected by the city on behalf of the state or federal government or fees charged by the city pursuant to a state or federal statute or regulation. (f) Temporary dwellings. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the city or its designees may issue temporary mobile home, trailer, recreational vehicle or other temporary dwelling structures or parks in any zoning district, even though not otherwise permitted by development code, while the primary dwelling is being repaired. The temporary permit shall not exceed six (6) months in duration. Upon expiration of the temporary permit and/or extension, the temporary dwelling must be removed. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) Sec. 2-264. - Registration of building and repair services. (a) In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-56, before building, constructing, repairing, renovating or making improvements to any real property, including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures or fixtures within an area in the city designated in a declared emergency or disaster, any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity must register with the city clerk and secure a building permit that is posted at the work site. Each day any such entity does business in the city without complying with this article constitutes a separate offense. (b) The cost of registration fees in a declared emergency or disaster is fixed at fifty dollars ($50.00) per annum. Registration is nontransferable. The cost of the emergency building permit shall be equal to the cost for a building permit under existing regulations. The permit shall only be authorized for repairs. (c) When registering, any person, partnership, corporation or other entity making application must, under oath, complete an application, providing the following information: (1) Name of applicant; (2) Permanent address and phone number of applicant; (3) Applicant's Social Security number or Federal Employer Identification number; (4) If applicant is a corporation, the state and date of incorporation; (5) Tag registration information for each vehicle to be used in the business; (6) List of cities and/or counties where the applicant has conducted business within the past twelve (12) months; (7) Georgia sales tax number or authorization; (8) Georgia business license number, if required; (9) Copy of license from Secretary of State, if required; (10) A signed and sworn affidavit verifying the applicant's legal presence in the United States as required by O.C.G.A. § 50-36-1; and (11) At least one (1) secure and verifiable document as defined in O.C.G.A. § 50-36-2. (d) Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon the signing of a declaration of emergency, stating this section is in effect. Unless otherwise specified in the declaration of emergency or otherwise extended by the city governing authority, the provisions of this Code section shall remain in effect during the state of emergency and for a subsequent recover period of three (3) months. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) Sec. 2-265. - Closed or restricted areas and curfews during emergency. (a) To preserve, protect or sustain the life, health, welfare or safety of persons, or their property, within a designated area under a declaration of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person to travel, loiter, wander or stroll in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, lanes, parks or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any other place during a declared emergency between hours specified by the mayor until the curfew is lifted. (b) To promote order, protect lives, minimize the potential for looting and other crimes, and facilitate recovery operations during an emergency, the mayor shall have discretion to impose reentry restrictions on certain areas. The mayor shall exercise such discretion in accordance with the applicable local emergency operations plan, which shall be followed during emergencies. (c) The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons acting in the following capacities: (1) Authorized and essential law enforcement personnel; (2) Authorized and essential health care providers; (3) Authorized and essential personnel of the city; (4) Authorized National Guard or federal military personnel; (5) Authorized and essential firefighters; (6) Authorized and essential emergency response personnel; (7) Authorized and essential personnel or volunteers working with or through an emergency management agency (EMA); (8) Authorized and essential utility repair crews; (9) Citizens seeking to restore order to their homes or businesses while on their own property or place of business; (10) Other authorized and essential persons as designated on a list compiled by the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.). (d) Enforceability. This section shall be enforced by officers of the law enforcement personnel approved to provide aid and assistance during the emergency. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit a law enforcement officer from bringing other charges under state law. (e) Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon the signing of a declaration of emergency, stating this section is in effect. (Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12)

div.head: Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to regulate the manufacture, sale or transportation of intoxicating liquors and alcoholic, malt and vinous beverages, § 1-103(17). State Law reference— Alcoholic beverages, OCGA Title 3.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 3-1. - Public drinking prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any malt, vinous or spirituous beverage or any other form of alcoholic beverage, mixed or plain, in or on any of the following places within the city: (1) Any street, alley, municipal building or facility, school or auditorium; (2) Any public place where games or contests are played, e.g., a baseball park, football field, tennis court and other places where people assemble to engage in or view games or athletic events; and (3) Any public parking lot and any parking area incidental to a commercial or industrial enterprise. (Ord. No. 80-9, 11-4-80) Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 12. Secs. 3-2—3-15. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SPIRITUOUS LIQUOR DEALERS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 3-16. - Purpose of article. This article has been enacted in accordance with a plan designed for the following purposes, among others: to promote the health and general welfare of the community, to establish reasonable standards for the regulation and control of the licensing and sales of spirituous liquors, to protect and preserve schools and churches, to give effect to existing land use and to preserve certain residential areas, with reasonable considerations, among others, to the character of the areas and their peculiar suitability for particular uses, the congestion in the roads and streets, and with a general view of promoting desirable living conditions and sustaining stability of neighborhood and property values, and to protect against the evils of concentration of the retail outlets for spirituous liquors in one (1) family or to prevent undesirable persons from controlling the retail liquor industry. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-17. - Definitions. Interest in license. As used in this article, an "interest in a license" shall be deemed to exist if the person involved is the outright owner of the license, a co-owner of the license, a partner in a partnership which owns all or any part of a license, a stockholder in any corporation organized for the pecuniary gain which owns all or any part of a license, an owner, lessor, sublessor or stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain owning or leasing any real estate which is occupied by a retail spirituous liquor store or shares in any of the income or corpus of any trust or estate having any interest in a retail spirituous liquor store; provided, however, that a stockholder shall not be deemed to have an interest in a retail spirituous liquor store where he owns stock in a motel or hotel having two hundred (200) or more rooms with a retail spirituous liquor store located on the premises of such motel or hotel and owned by such motel or hotel. Notwithstanding any of the other provisions of this section, no one (1) person shall have more than one (1) interest in any one (1) license in the city. Spirituous liquors. "Spirituous liquors" shall be deemed to include, but not be limited to, whiskey, rum, gin, brandy, vodka, tequila and all alcoholic beverages of similar nature and a similar alcoholic content. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. State Law reference— Similar definitions, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. Sec. 3-18. - Penalties for violation of article or application irregularities. (a) Any person who acquires a license or a renewal of same in violation of this article by any misrepresentation or fraudulent statement shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished in accordance with section 1-17. (b) Any untrue or misleading information contained in, or material omission left out of, an original, renewal or transfer application for a retail liquor license shall be cause for the denial thereof and if any license has been granted under these circumstances, there shall be cause for the revocation of same. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-19. - Retail licensee prohibited from having first direct financial interest in wholesale liquor business. No person shall hold a retail license who also has any direct financial interest in any wholesale liquor business. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-20. - Personal restrictions on interest in retail license. (a) After the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives, no person or member of his family shall own, hold or control any interest whatsoever in more than one (1) license to engage in the business of selling spirituous liquors at retail in the city. (b) No more than one (1) license to engage in the sale of spirituous liquors at retail in the city shall be issued to any person which shall include all members of such person's family. (c) "Family" shall be deemed to include any person related to the holder of such license within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as computed according to the civil law. (d) It shall be unlawful for any elected or appointed official or employee of the city, or his spouse or minor children, to have any whole, partial or beneficial interest in any license to operate retail spirituous liquor stores in the city. (e) A license may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined that the additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or expanding the facilities of the business or for building new facilities and where it appears that the licensee himself received directly none of the additional capital invested. Under this section an additional partner or stockholder must be approved by the mayor and council and, if approved, the business must obtain a new license. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-21. - Population restrictions on number of licenses issued. The mayor and council shall not issue any further spirituous liquor licenses when such issuance would cause the number of licenses to exceed one (1) for each five thousand (5,000) persons residing in the city. Such population figures shall be based on the most recent figures issued by the United States Census Bureau. (Ord. No. 82-9, 12-7-82; Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 9-18-07) Sec. 3-22. - Distance requirements for package sales of spirituous liquors. At a minimum, the front entrance of any business involved in the package sale of spirituous liquors must be located the distance specified below from the front entrance of any relevant building, unless otherwise specified herein. Using the most direct route of travel on the ground, measure as follows: (a) At least three hundred (300) feet from a business engaged in the package sale of spirituous liquors to an alcoholic treatment center; (b) At least three hundred (300) feet from a business engaged in the package sale of spirituous liquors to any church building; (c) At least six hundred (600) feet from a business engaged in the package sale of spirituous liquors to any school building or school grounds; (d) At least six hundred (600) feet from a business engaged in the package sale of spirituous liquors to a college campus; (e) At least three hundred (300) feet from an alcoholic treatment center to a business engaged in the package sale of spirituous liquors; (f) At least three hundred (300) feet from any church building to a business engaged in the package sale of spirituous liquors; (g) At least six hundred (600) feet from any school building or school grounds to a business engaged in the package sale of spirituous liquors; and (h) At least six hundred (600) feet from a college campus to a business engaged in the package sale of spirituous liquors. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 93-11, § 1, 12-21-93; Ord. No 2003-16, § 1, 10-21-03; Ord. No. 2010-14, § 1, 9-21-10) State Law reference— Sales of alcoholic beverages near churches, school buildings, etc., O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. Sec. 3-23. - "Schools, colleges" defined. The schools or colleges referred to in this section shall include only such state, county, city, church or other schools as teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state, and shall not include private schools or colleges wherein only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects, are taught. For the purposes of this section, "schools" shall not include day care centers, or facilities which participate in Georgia's Pre-K Program. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 94-11, § 1, 6-21-94; Ord. No 2003-16, § 2, 10-21-03; Ord. No. 2010-14, § 2, 9-21-10) Sec. 3-24. - Zoning regulations for a licensed location. No license to engage in the package sale of spirituous liquors shall be issued within the areas described in this article unless the location has been zoned GC, RSC, M-1, M-2, TCMU or TCMF under the zoning laws of the city. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 87-8, 2-3-87; Ord. No 2003-16, § 3, 10-21-03; Ord. No. 2007-08, § 1, 4-17-07) Sec. 3-25. - Annexed areas; continuance of business. Where a retail liquor store exists on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives in an area outside the city limits, upon annexation of such area the same may be continued and shall be subject to all provisions of this article except that part that pertains to residences. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Secs. 3-26—3-35. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Licenses and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 9. State Law reference— Local license required, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-3-2, 3-4-40, 3-5-40, 3-6-40.
Sec. 3-36. - Qualifications of applicant. (a) No retail license for spirituous liquors shall be granted to any applicant who is not a citizen of the United States or permanent resident alien thereof and who has not resided continuously in the state for twelve (12) months next preceding the year for which application is made. Where the applicant is a corporation whose primary business is the operation of a liquor store, the majority stockholder must meet the within requirements and the license shall be issued to the corporation and the majority stockholders. Where the applicant is a corporation whose primary business is other than the operation of a liquor store, the license shall be issued to the corporation and an officer or agent of such corporation who meets the above requirements. If the applicant is a partnership, the within requirements shall apply to all partners. (b) All applicants for licenses must attach to their application evidence of their good character. No original license shall be issued to any person, partnership or corporation organized for pecuniary gain where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner, stockholder, directly or indirectly beneficial or absolute, shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of the application for any felony or misdemeanor of any state or of the United States or any municipal ordinance except traffic violations. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 82-5, 8-17-82; Ord. No. 87-31, § 1, 10-20-87; Ord. No. 2014-07, § 1, 8-19-14) Sec. 3-37. - Pending applications. All applications now pending for the year 1972 for the issuance of retail liquor licenses shall be considered under this article without further filing. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-38. - Application. (a) Contents. All applications for license under the provisions of this article, both original and renewal, must be accompanied by a full and complete statement under oath of information relative to any and all interest in retail packaged spirituous liquor stores. This shall include the names and addresses of all persons interested in the ownership of the business of selling at retail packaged spirituous liquor, together with any interest each person or any member of his immediate family has in any other retail packaged spirituous liquor store; the ownership of the land and building where such retail business is operated; the amount of rental paid for such land and building and the manner in which the same is determined and to whom and at what intervals it is paid; the names and addresses (by affidavit from the owner, lessor or sublessor of such land and building) of all persons having any whole, partial, beneficial or other interest in and to the land and building on and in which such retail packaged spirituous liquor store is located; and any other information called for by the mayor and council. (b) Change in relationship. Any change in any relationship declared must be filed with the police department when such change is made, and failure to so file within a period of thirty (30) days after such change is made shall be grounds for cancellation by the mayor and council. (c) Property survey. All applications shall include a certificate from a registered surveyor showing a scale drawing of the location of the proposed or existing premises and the distance from the proposed or existing front entrance of the proposed or existing premises to the front entrance of the buildings of the nearest alcoholic treatment centers, churches, schools, colleges and housing authority properties. The scale drawing shall show measurements of all relevant distances utilizing the most direct route of travel on the ground. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No 2003-16, § 4, 10-21-03) Sec. 3-39. - Physical requirements of applicant's premises. (a) No license shall be granted to a retailer, under the provisions of this article, unless the front entrance to the premises is clearly visible from a public street; provided, however, that this restriction shall not apply where the licensee is a hotel, motel, private club, location in a shopping center or multiple-story business building. (b) Where a building in which a retailer intends to operate under the provisions of this article is at the time of the application for such license not in existence or not yet completed, license may be issued for such location provided the plans for the proposed building show clearly a compliance with the other provisions of this article. (c) No sales shall be made from such establishment until it has been completed in accordance with the plans and is in conformity with all of the other provisions of this article. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-40. - Notice of application for license. All persons desiring to engage in the sale of spirituous liquors at retail in the city shall give notice of the purpose of making such application by advertisement in at least two (2) consecutive issues of the legal organ of the city plus five (5) times on different days in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city, which notice shall contain a particular description of the location of the proposed spirituous liquor business and shall give the name of the applicant, and if a partnership the names of the partners, and if a corporation, the names of the officers and all stockholders. The advertisement referred to herein shall be of type not smaller than ten-point capital and lowercase and shall be at least a one-inch, two-column advertisement. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-41. - Investigation of applicant. (a) All applications for new licenses for sale of packaged spirituous liquor at retail and all applications for renewal of such new licenses shall be investigated by the police department and no such new or renewal license shall be acted upon by the mayor and council or issued by the city clerk until the city attorney has indicated in writing that, in his opinion, upon the facts as stated and ascertained by the police department, no violation exists as to any ordinance in effect as of the date of the rendering of such opinion. All applications for new or renewal licenses shall furnish to the police department all data, information and records requested of them by the police department and failure to furnish such data, information and records within thirty (30) days from the date of the request by the police department shall automatically serve to dismiss with prejudice the application of any such applicant failing to furnish such data, information and records. (b) Applicants, by filing for license to sell packaged spirituous liquor at retail, agree to furnish the data, information and records as called for herein and also agree to submit under oath to interrogation by the police department or the city attorney as to any facts considered pertinent to such application. Applicants, by filing such application, also agree to produce for oral interrogation by the police department or the city attorney, any person or persons requested by the police department and considered as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to the license. Failure to produce such persons within thirty (30) days after being requested to do so shall result in the automatic dismissal of any application for license. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-42. - Public hearing on application. All applications for licenses for the retail sale of spirituous liquors shall be acted upon by the mayor and council after a public hearing after advertisement as required by law, such advertisement to be made as provided in section 3-40, and proof of same furnished to the mayor and council prior to the hearing. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-43. - Action by mayor and council; time limitation. All applications for new licenses under this article or for transfers of locations shall be passed upon by the mayor and council within sixty (60) days from the date of the filing of such application. Date of filing shall be the time and date that a properly completed and executed application form along with the filing fee as required in section 3-45(2) is received by the city clerk. The city clerk shall not accept an application for consideration by the mayor and council when there is a previously filed application for a place of business for a retail spirituous liquor license within five hundred (500) feet of the applicant's proposed site. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-44. - Grant of application. All applications to engage in the sale at retail of spirituous liquors meeting the standards of this article shall be granted, unless some specific cause related to location, traffic condition or other environmental condition shall justify refusal. In such case, the applicant shall be entitled to file a new application for a license at an eligible location without loss of any part of his application or license fee. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-45. - Annual license fee schedule. (a) The annual license fee for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling spirituous liquors at retail shall be an amount as set by resolution of the city council, which amount shall remain in effect until modified or amended by subsequent resolution adopted by the city council. The sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be paid at the time an original application is filed to cover investigative costs, which shall be credited against the first annual license fee upon grant of a license. This fee is not refundable. (b) All retailer license fees shall be paid between January first and January twentieth each year. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 2014-10, § 1, 11-18-14) Sec. 3-46. - Issuance. (a) All licenses under this division must be obtained and fees paid not later than two (2) weeks from the date of the approval of the application by the mayor and council and, if not so obtained, the permit granted by the mayor and council shall be void. (b) When a license has been approved, and the applicant has deposited with the clerk of the mayor and council the required fee, the fee shall be paid to the municipal revenue collector and a license issued. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-47. - Procedure when license denied by state. If the applicant is denied a license by the state, upon the proof of such refusal, he shall be entitled to a refund of the license fee less the investigative fee as required in section 3-45(2) plus an additional charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to cover clerical costs of granting the license. The refund may be made by the city clerk without the necessity of any action by the mayor and council. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-48. - Duration. No license shall be issued for less than a calendar year period and in case of the revocation or surrender of such license before the expiration of such calendar year period, the holder thereof shall not be entitled to receive any refund whatsoever. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-49. - Business to be opened within nine months from license issuance; effect of failure to do so. (a) All holders of licenses for the retail sale of spirituous liquors must within nine (9) months after the issuance of the license open for business the establishment referred to in the license and begin the sale of the product or products authorized by the license. (b) Failure to open the establishment and begin the sale as referred to in subsection (a) above within the nine-month period shall serve as automatic forfeiture and cancellation of the unused license and no refund of license fees shall be made to the license holder. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-50. - Effect of failure to operate business for nine consecutive months. Any holder of a license for the retail sale of spirituous liquors who shall begin the operation of the business and sale of the product or products as authorized in the license but who shall for a period of nine (9) consecutive months thereafter cease to operate the business and sale of the product or products authorized in such license, shall upon completion of the nine-month period automatically forfeit his license, which license shall, by virtue of such failure to operate be canceled without the necessity of any further action of the mayor and council. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-51. - Transferability. (a) Licenses to engage in the business of selling spirituous liquors at retail shall not be transferable, except as otherwise provided in this section. (b) In case of the death of any person holding such a license, or any interest therein, the same may, in the discretion of the city administrator, be transferred to the administrator, executor or the lawful heirs of the deceased person. (c) Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one (1) or more of the partners in a partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership in favor of one (1) or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. Such withdrawal shall not, however, serve to bring any new ownership into the partnership. (d) Should a transfer of a location be approved by the city administrator, there shall be no pro rata return of any license fee and the new location shall be considered as a new license hereunder. (e) All applications for transfer of locations shall comply with the provisions herein set forth governing new licenses. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 91-12, § 1, 11-19-91) Sec. 3-52. - Suspension or revocation. (a) Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license to sell at retail any spirituous liquors the city license to deal in such products shall thereupon be automatically revoked without any action by the mayor and council or any municipal officer. (b) No license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued by the city to any person as a retail dealer in spirituous liquors shall be suspended or revoked, except for due cause as hereinafter defined, and after a hearing and upon the prior three-day written notice to the holder of such. (c) "Due cause" for the suspension or revocation of such license shall consist of the violation of any laws or ordinances regulating such businesses, or violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating such businesses, or for the violation of any state or federal law, or for the violation of any city ordinances other than traffic ordinances, which in the opinion of the mayor and council deem to render the licensee improper to hold such license. (d) Such hearings shall be conducted by the mayor and council. (e) Upon a finding of "due cause" for suspension or revocation by the mayor and council against the licensee, the following minimum penalties shall apply: (1) First offense—Three-day suspension; (2) Second offense—Ten-day suspension and one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) fine; (3) Third offense—Thirty-day suspension and one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) fine; and (4) Fourth offense—Revocation for minimum of two (2) years. (f) In the event of revocation, no refund of any portion of the license shall be paid. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 94-9, §§ 1, 2, 5-17-94) Secs. 3-53—3-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - OPERATING REGULATIONS
Sec. 3-61. - Front window display. Each person licensed to sell spirituous liquor at retail shall have printed on the front window of the licensed premises the inscription "City Retail License No. " in uniform letters not less than four (4) inches in height; provided, however, that if a licensee so desires he may have his name displayed on the inside of the window in like manner or in neon or other electric lights. Such sign shall be parallel with the window and so constructed as not to extend more than six (6) inches from the window. A neon sign may also be constructed along the borderline or edge of the front window inside the glass. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-62. - Exterior advertisement of brand and price of liquor prohibited. No sign of any kind, painted or electric, advertising any brand or price of liquor shall be permitted on the exterior, or in the window, of any licensed premises. No placard or sign of any kind which is visible from the exterior of the licensed premises shall make reference to the price of any liquors sold therein; provided, however, that tags showing the prices of individual bottles or containers may be affixed to each such bottle or container or to the edge of the shelf whereon such bottles or containers are located. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-63. - Interior visibility required; license prohibited in restaurant, etc. (a) No screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing, which shall prevent a clear view into the interior, shall be permitted in the window or upon the doors of any retail spirituous liquor store, and no booth, screen, partition or other obstruction shall be permitted within the interior of any such store. Each such retail store shall be so lighted that the interior of the store is visible day and night. (b) No retail spirituous liquor license shall be allowed in, or in connection with, any restaurant, cafe or eating place, or in the same room where a bar or soda fountain is maintained for the dispensing and sale of soft drinks or other beverages. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-64. - Business hours and days. Retail dealers in spirituous liquors shall not engage in the sale of such liquors except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. Monday through Saturday and 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. Sunday. The business hours of wholesale dealers shall be from sunup to sundown. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 84-1, § 1, 1-17-84; Ord. No. 90-12, §§ 1, 2, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 11-15-11; Ord. No. 2014-11, § 1, 11-18-14) State Law reference— Municipal authority to authorize sale of alcoholic beverages on local election days, OCGA § 3-3-20(b)(2)(B); municipal authority to prohibit sales of alcoholic beverages on Christmas Day, OCGA § 3-3-20(c); municipal authority to regulate the sale of alcoholic beverages at stated times, OCGA § 37-8-11(b). Sec. 3-65. - Deliveries of alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful to make deliveries of alcoholic beverages except in the store or department of the store in which such beverages are sold. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-66. - Slot machines, etc., prohibited on premises. No retail dealer shall permit on his premises any slot machine or mechanical music boxes or pinball machines or any kind or character or any coin-operated machines operated for amusement purposes. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-67. - Price lists or tags. Each retail licensee of spirituous liquors shall have conspicuously displayed within the interior of the licensed premises not less than four (4) copies of a printed price list of the spirituous liquors offered for sale and one (1) printed copy of the penal sections of this article; provided, however that a licensee, in lieu of having four (4) copies of a printed price list, may have the price placed on the bottles or on the bottom of the shelf where liquors are exhibited for sale. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-68. - Employees; reports to police; investigation; fee. (a) No retail licensee of spirituous liquors shall employ any minor in his store, or in the department of a store where alcoholic beverages are sold. No retail licensee shall employ in any premises used for the sale of spirituous liquors any person in any capacity whatsoever who has been convicted in this or any state or by the United States or any other country of soliciting for prostitution, keeping a disorderly place, illegally dealing in narcotics, sex offenses or any charge relating to unlawful manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquors or and other crime involving moral turpitude. (b) It shall be the duty of all persons holding retail or wholesale licenses to sell alcoholic beverages to file with the chief of police the names of all employees with their home addresses and home telephone numbers and places of employment. Changes in the list of employees, with the names of new employees, must be filed with the chief of police within three (3) days from the date of such change. All employees shall be subject to such investigative rules and regulations as may be deemed necessary from time to time by the police department of the city. A five-dollar investigative fee shall be paid by all applicants. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-69. - Sales to minors and intoxicated persons prohibited. No licensee authorized to sell spirituous liquors at retail in Union City, Georgia, nor any agent or employee of any licensee, shall do any of the following upon the licensed premises: (1) Sell, give, provide, furnish, or cause to be furnished any spirituous liquor to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age; (2) Sell, give, provide, furnish, or cause to be furnished any spirituous liquor to any person who is in a state of noticeable intoxication. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 94-8, § 1, 5-17-94) Sec. 3-70. - Sanitary regulations, immoral conduct, etc.; inspection and report by fire department. (a) All premises licensed under the provisions of this division shall be kept clean and in proper sanitary condition and in full compliance with the provisions and regulations governing the condition of premises used for the storage and sale of food for human consumption. It shall be unlawful to permit any disturbance of the peace, any obscenity or any lewd, immoral or improper entertainment, conduct or practice on such premises. (b) The fire department shall, upon request of the police committee, inspect such premises and report their findings to the committee. All premises licensed under this division shall conform at all times with all fire regulations of the city. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Secs. 3-71—3-85. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - VINOUS LIQUOR DEALERS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 3-86. - Purpose. This article has been enacted in accordance with a plan designed for the following purposes, among others: to promote health and general welfare of the community, to establish reasonable standards for the regulation and control of the licensing and sales of vinous liquors, to protect and preserve schools and churches, to give effect to existing land use and to preserve certain residential areas, with reasonable considerations, among others, to the character of the areas and their particular suitability for particular uses, the congestion in the roads and streets, and with a general view of promoting desirable living conditions and sustaining stability of neighborhood and property values and to protect against evils of concentration of outlets for vinous liquors in one (1) family or to prevent undesirable persons from controlling the vinous liquor industry. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-87. - Definitions. Interest in license. As used in this article, an "interest in a license" shall be deemed to exist if the person involved is the outright owner of the license, a co-owner of the license, a partner in a partnership which owns all or any part of a license, a stockholder in any corporation organized for the pecuniary gain which owns all or any part of a license, an owner, lessor, sublessor or stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain owning or leasing any real estate which is occupied by a vinous liquor store or shares in any of the income or corpus of any trust fund or estate having any interest in a vinous liquor store; provided, however, that a stockholder shall not be deemed to have an interest in a vinous liquor store where he owns stock in a motel or hotel having two hundred (200) or more rooms with a vinous liquor store located on the premises of such motel or hotel and owned by such motel or hotel. Notwithstanding any of the other provisions of this section, no one (1) person shall have an interest in more than two (2) licenses. Vinous liquors. "Vinous liquors" shall mean any and all wines, fortified and unfortified, produced either within or without the state and containing not more than twenty-one (21) percent alcohol by volume. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. State Law reference— Similar definitions, OCGA § 3-1-2. Sec. 3-88. - Penalties for violations or application irregularities. (a) Any person who acquires a license or a renewal of same in violation of this article by any misrepresentation or fraudulent statement shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished in accordance with this Code. (b) Any untrue or misleading information contained in, or material omission left out of, an original, renewal or transfer application for a license shall be cause for the denial thereof and, if any license has been granted under these circumstances, there shall be cause for the revocation of same. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-89. - Retail license prohibited from having direct financial interest in wholesale liquor business. No person shall hold a retail license who also has any direct financial interest in any wholesale liquor business. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-90. - Personal restrictions on interest in retail business. (a) Not more than one (1) license to engage in the sale of vinous liquors in the city shall be issued to any person which shall include all members of such person's family. (b) Family shall be deemed to include any person related to the holder of such license within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as computed according to the civil law. (c) After the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, no person or member of his family shall own, hold or control any interest whatsoever in more than two (2) licenses to engage in the business of selling vinous liquors. (d) It shall be unlawful for any elected or appointed official or employee of the city, or his spouse or minor children, to have any whole, partial, or beneficial interest in any license to operate any vinous liquor store in the city. (e) A license may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined that the additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or expanding the facilities of the business or for building new facilities and where it appears that the licensee himself received directly none of the additional capital invested. Under this section an additional partner or stockholder must be approved by the mayor and council and, if approved, the business must obtain a new license. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Sec. 3-91. - Distance requirements for package sales of vinous liquor. At a minimum, the front entrance of any business involved in the package sale of vinous liquors must be located the distance specified below from the front entrance of any relevant building, unless otherwise specified herein. Using the most direct route of travel on the ground, measure as follows: (a) At least three hundred (300) feet from a business engaged in the package sale of vinous liquors to an alcoholic treatment center; (b) At least three hundred (300) feet from a business engaged in the package sale of vinous liquors to any school building or school grounds; (c) At least three hundred (300) feet from a business engaged in the package sale of vinous liquors to a college campus; (d) At least three hundred (300) feet from an alcoholic treatment center to a business engaged in the package sale of vinous liquors; (e) At least three hundred (300) feet from any school building or school grounds to a business engaged in the package sale of vinous liquors; and (f) At least three hundred (300) feet from a college campus to a business engaged in the package sale of vinous liquors. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 93-11, § 2, 12-21-93; Ord. No 2003-16, § 5, 10-21-03; Ord. No. 2010-14, § 3, 9-21-10) Sec. 3-92. - "Schools, colleges" defined. The schools or colleges referred to in this section shall include only such state, county, city, church or other schools as teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state, and shall not include private schools or colleges wherein only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects, are taught. For the purposes of this section, "schools" shall not include day care centers, or facilities which participate in Georgia's Pre-K Program. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 94-11, § 2, 6-21-94; Ord. No 2003-16, § 6 10-21-03; Ord. No. 2010-14, § 4, 9-21-10) Sec. 3-93. - Zoning regulations for a licensed location. No license to engage in the package sale of vinous liquors shall be issued within the areas described in this article unless the location has been zoned GC, RSC, M-1, M-2, TCMU or TCMF under the zoning laws of the city. (Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 87-8, § 1, 2-3-87; Ord. No 2003-16, § 7, 10-21-03; Ord. No. 2007-08, § 2, 4-17-07) Sec. 3-94. - Annexed areas; continuance of business. Where a vinous liquor store exists on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, in an area outside the city limits, upon annexation of such area the same may be continued and shall be subject to all provisions of this article except that part that pertains to residences. (Code 1976, § 15-201) Secs. 3-95—3-105. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSES[3]
