(c) Each registrant shall file with the city manager a registration form setting out the following information: (1) The real property owner's name, street address, mailing address, phone number, facsimile number, and e-mail address; (2) If applicable, the agent's name, street address, mailing address, phone number, facsimile number, and e-mail address; (3) The real property's street address and tax parcel number; (4) The transfer date of the instrument conveying the real property to the owner; and (5) At such time as it becomes available, recording information, including deed book and page numbers, of the instrument conveying the real property to the owner. (Ord. No. 2012-13, § 1, 7-17-12) Sec. 5-273. - Transfers. (a) When any real property is acquired by foreclosure under power of sale pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 44-14-160 or acquired pursuant to a deed in lieu of foreclosure, the transferee shall not be required to register such foreclosed real property pursuant to this article or pay any of the administrative fees provided for in section 5-276 of this article where: (1) The deed under power of sale or deed in lieu of foreclosure contains the information specified in subsection 5-272(c)(1) through (5); (2) The deed is filed with the clerk of superior court within sixty (60) days of the transfer; and (3) Proof of the following is provided to the city manager: (i) A filing date stamp or a receipt showing payment of the applicable filing fees; and (ii) The entire deed under power of sale or entire deed in lieu of foreclosure. (b) Registration of vacant or foreclosed real property is not required within ninety (90) days of such real property's transfer: (1) Pursuant to a deed under power of sale or deed in lieu of foreclosure; or (2) To the first subsequent transferee after the vacant real property has been acquired by foreclosure under power of sale pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 44-14-160 or acquired pursuant to a deed in lieu of foreclosure. Once the aforementioned ninety-day period has expired, registration of such vacant or foreclosed property must be made within thirty (30) days of said expiration. (Ord. No. 2012-13, § 1, 7-17-12) Sec. 5-274. - Updating of information. The owner of vacant or foreclosed real property registered with the city shall update the information specified in subsection 5-272(c)(1) through (5) within thirty (30) days after any change in such required information regardless of whether the information provided to the registry was in the deed under power of sale or deed in lieu of foreclosure. (Ord. No. 2012-13, § 1, 7-17-12) Sec. 5-275. - Removal from registry. The owner of vacant or foreclosed real property registered with the city, or the agent of such owner, may apply to remove such vacant or foreclosed real property from the registry at such time as the real property no longer constitutes vacant or foreclosed real property. Such application shall be considered by the city manager, whose determination shall be issued within thirty (30) days of the receipt of said application. If no such determination is made within thirty (30) days, the application shall be deemed granted. (Ord. No. 2012-13, § 1, 7-17-12) Sec. 5-276. - Administrative fees. Upon the submission of the registration required in section 5-272, the owner of such vacant or foreclosed real property, or the agent of such owner, shall pay to the city an administrative fee which shall be established by the mayor and council and which shall not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) per registration. Said fee shall reasonably approximate the cost to the city of the establishment, maintenance, operation, and administration of the registry. (Ord. No. 2012-13, § 1, 7-17-12) Sec. 5-277. - Violations. Failure to register vacant or foreclosed real property or failure to update the information specified in subsection 5-272(c)(1) through (5) shall be punishable by a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. No. 2012-13, § 1, 7-17-12) Sec. 5-278. - Appeals. Any vacant or foreclosed real property owner affected by this article may challenge any determination made by the city or its officials pursuant to this article by appealing said determination to the Municipal Court of the City of Union City. Such appeal shall be filed with the court no later than thirty (30) days after receipt of said determination. (Ord. No. 2012-13, § 1, 7-17-12)

div.head: Chapter 6 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to provide fire protection, § 1-102(c)(1); authority to regulate the transportation, use and storage of explosives and flammable material and the use of heating equipment, § 1-103(17); authority to provide for fire safety regulations, § 1-103(23). Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; health and sanitation, Ch. 8; fireworks prohibited, § 10-11; fire lanes, § 14-31; utilities, Ch. 15. State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for fire protection, Ga. Const. 1983, Art. IX, Sec. II, Para. III(a)(1); fire protection and safety, OCGA Title 25.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Schedule of fees. In addition to those fees provided for by article VI of this chapter, the fire chief shall be authorized to collect fees for the provision of certain services by the fire department and its personnel. Said fees shall be as set forth in a schedule of fees duly adopted by the mayor and council for the City of Union City. (Ord. No. 2015-01, § 3, 4-21-15) Secs. 6-2—6-15. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Authority to prescribe fire safety regulations, § 1-103(23); authority of mayor and council to adopt codes of technical regulations, § 2-406. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5.
Sec. 6-16. - Adopted. There is hereby adopted by the mayor and city council, for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, that certain code known as the Standard Fire Prevention Code, 1991 Edition, except for such portions as may be deleted, modified or amended in this article, of which code not less than one copy has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk. The same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1976, § 5-101; Ord. No. 91-10, § 1, 10-15-91) State Law reference— Municipal authority to adopt fire codes, OCGA § 25-3-4. Sec. 6-17. - Definitions. (a) Wherever the words "chief of the bureau of fire prevention" are used in the fire prevention code, they shall be held to mean the chief of the fire department of the city, and whenever the words "bureau of fire prevention" are used in such code, they shall be held to mean the fire department of the city. (b) Wherever the term "corporation counsel" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the city attorney. (c) Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean this city. (Code 1976, § 5-102) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 6-18. - Enforcement of code. This code shall be administered and enforced, as provided within the Standard Fire Prevention Code, by the fire prevention department. The City of Union City Fire Department shall be designated as such fire prevention department. The fire chief shall hereby be appointed as the fire official with such duties and responsibilities as provided for by said code. (Code 1976, § 5-103; Ord. No. 91-10, § 2, 10-15-91) Sec. 6-19. - Power to make modifications. (a) The chief of the fire department shall be authorized to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee of any property, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the ways of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed and the public safety secured. (b) The particulars of such modifications when granted or allowed, and the decision of the fire chief thereon, shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be forwarded to the applicant. (Code 1976, § 5-104) Sec. 6-20. - Reserved. Sec. 6-21. - Knox boxes. (a) Where required. Where access to or within a structure or an area is restricted because of secured openings or where immediate access is necessary for life-saving or fire-fighting purposes, the fire chief or fire marshal is authorized to require a knox box to be installed in an approved location. The knox box shall be of an approved type and shall contain keys to gain necessary access as required by the fire chief or fire marshal. (b) Locks. An approved knox lock shall be installed on gates or similar barrier when required by the fire chief or fire marshal. (c) Knox box maintenance. The operator of the building shall immediately notify the fire chief or fire marshal and provide the new key when a lock is changed or rekeyed. The key to such lock shall be secured in the knox box. (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 5-17-11; Ord. No. 2011-12, § 1, 8-16-11) Sec. 6-22. - Use and storage of grills. No grill may be used or stored in breezeways, balconies/patios, stairways, or exit access areas. (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 2, 5-17-11; Ord. No. 2011-12, § 2, 8-16-11) Sec. 6-23. - Electric coil cooking devices. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used inthis section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection: Apartment building shall mean a building or portion thereof containing three (3) or more dwelling units with independent cooking and bathroom facilities. Electric coil cooking device shall mean a cooking device that utilizes a coil for the cooking heat source. This term shall include freestanding and built-in electric ranges "drop in" type counter-top cook tops, and hot plates. High end heat limiting technology shall mean a device that is hard-wired into the electric coil range (tamper proof) that limits the high end cooking temperature to a safe level so as to prevent auto-ignition of common cooking and household materials. Nursing home shall mean a building or portion of a building used on a twenty-four-hour basis for the housing and nursing care of four (4) or more persons who, because of mental or physical incapacity, might be unable to provide for their own needs and safety without the assistance of another person. Residential board and care occupancy shall mean a building or portion thereof that is used for lodging and boarding of four (4) or more residents, not related by blood or marriage to the owners or operators, for the purpose of providing personal care services. This term shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following types of facilities: (1) Facilities containing group housing arrangements for physically or mentally handicapped persons who normally attend school in the community, attend worship in the community, or otherwise use community facilities. (2) Facilities containing group housing arrangements for physically or mentally handicapped persons who are undergoing training in preparation for independent living, for paid employment, or for other normal community activities. (3) Facilities containing group housing arrangements for the elderly that provide personal care services but that do not provide nursing care. (4) Facilities for social rehabilitation, alcoholism, drug abuse, or mental health problems that contain a group housing arrangement and that provide personal care services but do not provide acute care. (5) Assisted living facilities. Tax supported housing shall mean any housing that is initially constructed by, and/or rent-subsidized by the taxpayers for the purpose of providing affordable housing for the at-need citizens within the jurisdiction of the city. This term shall also include privately-owned rental properties for which the rent is subsidized by the taxpayers. (b) As of the effective date of this section, all electric coil cooking devices purchased for the purpose of replacement in existing apartment buildings, nursing homes, tax supported housing, or facilities used for residential board and care occupancy or purchased as standard equipment in new apartment buildings, nursing homes, tax supported housing, or facilities used for residential board and care occupancy shall be equipped with listed and approved high end heat limiting technology. (Ord. No. 2012-20, § 1, 9-18-12; Ord. No. 2017-02, § 1, 3-21-17) Secs. 6-24—6-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FIRE HYDRANT CODE[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Charter reference— Authority of mayor and council to adopt codes of technical regulations, § 2-406.
Sec. 6-31. - Adopted. There is hereby adopted for the purpose of establishing standards and procedures affecting the design, erection and construction of fire hydrants the AWWA Standard for Dry-Barrel Fire Hydrants, C 502, and 1973 Edition, and the foreword thereunto, as promulgated by the American Water Works Association, Inc., of which sketches labeled "A" and "B" are attached thereto, and of which not less than one (1) copy has been and is on file in the office of the city clerk, and save and except such portions as are hereinafter stricken or modified, is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) State Law reference— Municipal authority to adopt fire codes, O.C.G.A. § 25-3-4. Sec. 6-32. - Spacing. (a) Single-family residential areas. Maximum distance between hydrants shall be not more than five hundred (500) feet. Maximum distance from hydrant to any building shall be not more than four hundred (400) feet from nearest hydrant. Distance shall be measured along the necessary route of travel. (b) Multifamily dwelling units, commercial areas, industrial areas, other high value areas. Maximum distance between hydrants shall be not more than four hundred (400) feet. Maximum distance from hydrant to the furthest part of any building shall be not more than four hundred (400) feet from nearest hydrant. Distance shall be measured along the necessary route of travel. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-33. - Connecting hydrants to water mains. All fire hydrants and valves need to be rodded to the water main. No pipe less than six (6) inches inside diameter shall be used for connection of hydrants to water mains and in high value areas it is recommended that not less than eight-inch pipe be used. All pipes shall be looped in a gridiron so that no leg is more than six hundred (600) feet long unless both ends are tied into the water main. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-34. - Valves. Valves shall be installed at every hydrant to make it possible to shut off parts of the piping system for repairs and extensions without putting large sections out of service. These valves shall be installed at intervals so that it is not necessary to cut off more than five hundred (500) feet in high value districts and not more than eight hundred (800) feet in other areas, and arranged so that flow may be maintained through arterial mains. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-35. - Location. (a) Hydrants when installed at intersections of streets shall be located a minimum of six (6) feet from the corner of such intersection in order to prevent damage from vehicles. (b) Hydrants shall be installed so that the maximum distance from the curb or street is six (6) feet and the minimum distance is three (3) feet. (c) All hydrants shall be set in such a manner that the lowest nozzle opening is a minimum of eighteen (18) inches above the finish grade level and a maximum of twenty-four (24) inches above the grade level. (d) All hydrants shall be set with a four-and-one-half-inch outlet facing the street. (e) The base of all hydrants shall be set in a minimum of four (4) square feet of crushed rock in order to provide access for the hydrant barrel to drain. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-36. - Parking. All hydrants shall be located so as to discourage parking in front of and near them. When it is necessary to locate hydrants in or near parking areas, curbing or other means shall be used to prevent the blocking of hydrants by vehicles. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Cross reference— Parking, stopping and standing, § 14-31 et seq. Sec. 6-37. - Bury length. The bury length of fire hydrants shall be a minimum of two and five-tenths (2.5) feet. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-38. - Number of hose and pumper outlet nozzles. Each fire hydrant shall have two (2), two-and-one-half-inch hose nozzles and one (1) four-and-one-half-inch steamer nozzles. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-39. - Type of outlet nozzle threads. All fire hydrant outlet nozzle threads must be in conformity with NFPA No. 194 for national (American) standard fire coupling screw threads. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-40. - Direction of rotation of operating nut. There must be counterclockwise rotation of the square operating nut on fire hydrants. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-41. - Size. The nominal diameter of the main valve of all fire hydrants shall be six (6) inches. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-42. - Size of joints. The inlet connection of all fire hydrants shall be six (6) inches in nominal diameter. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Sec. 6-43. - Color. All fire hydrants must be of aluminum color. (Ord. No. 78-5, 8-15-78) Secs. 6-44—6-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Departments generally, § 2-121 et seq. State Law reference— Local fire departments generally, OCGA Title 25, Ch. 3.
Sec. 6-61. - Composition and rank. (a) Composition. The fire department shall consist of a chief and such subordinate officers and firemen as may from time to time be provided for by the mayor and city council, provided that the mayor and council may contract with the Union City Volunteer Fire Department, Inc., a nonprofit corporation of the state, to provide for personnel including a chief and assistant chief and firemen. (b) Rank. Following the fire chief in rank shall be the captain, the lieutenants, the sergeants and the firemen, in order of seniority in each group. (Code 1976, § 3-603) Sec. 6-62. - Fire chief. (a) Appointment. The fire chief shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of city council, and shall be the chief executive officer of the fire department, subject always to the orders and regulations of the mayor and council. (b) Powers and duties. The fire chief shall be responsible for and have control over the fire department and all fire apparatus belonging to the city, and he shall have the following additional duties: (1) To see to the proper and speedy extinguishment of all accidental or intentionally caused fires; (2) To see to the enforcement of the fire prevention code adopted by the mayor and council; (3) To keep or cause to be kept adequate records of all fires, inspections, equipment, fire prevention efforts and other activities of the department; (4) To submit a report to the mayor and council on the activities of the department when requested to do so; (5) To establish rules and regulations concerning the discipline, good order, proper conduct, care and management of the fire department, subject to approval by the city council; (6) To investigate the causes of all extended or destructive fires occurring within the city. (Code 1976, § 3-603) Sec. 6-63. - Firemen—Qualifications, physical fitness requirements. (a) Qualifications. Any person employed by the city as a fireman shall have the following qualifications: (1) Be at least eighteen (18) years of age; (2) Have a high school diploma or a G.E.D. equivalent; (3) Have not been convicted of a felony within ten (10) years prior to employment; (4) Have good moral character as determined by investigation under the procedure approved by the state firefighters standards and training council; (5) Be in good physical condition as determined by a medical examination approved by the council; (6) Complete at least a basic training course of one hundred twenty (120) hours of instruction within twelve (12) months after being appointed a full-time, paid member of the department (if the department employs three (3) or more firemen); and (7) Train, drill or study in council-approved schools, classes or courses at least one hundred twenty (120) hours in each calendar year following the first year of employment. (b) Minimum physical fitness requirements. Each candidate for the position of fireman shall meet the following physical fitness requirements: (1) The candidate, after successfully completing the medical examination and with written authorization of the examining physician, shall run one and one-half (1½) miles within twelve (12) minutes; (2) The candidate will perform twenty-five (25) bent-knee sit-ups within ninety (90) seconds; (3) The candidate shall, from a completely extended arm position, pull the body upward so as to chin the horizontal bar being grasped by the hands, palms away, a total of five (5) consecutive times; (4) The candidate shall, from a horizontal position, successfully accomplish ten (10) push-ups as prescribed by the authority having jurisdiction; (5) The candidate, given a beam secured to a level floor and measuring twenty (20) feet long by three (3) to four (4) inches wide, and given a length of fire hose weighing at least twenty (20) pounds, shall walk the length of the beam carrying the length of the hose without falling off or stepping off the beam; (6) The candidate, given a weight of one hundred twenty-five (125) pounds, shall lift the weight from the floor and carry the weight one hundred (100) feet without stopping; and (7) The candidate, starting from an erect position with feet apart, the distance closely approximating shoulder width, shall move a fifteen-pound weight in the following manner: bend over, grasp the weight with both hands while it is at a point on the floor between the feet, and lift the weight to waist level, then place the weight on the floor approximately twelve (12) inches outside the left foot, and without letting go, raise the weight to waist level and touch it to the floor about twelve (12) inches outside the right foot. The weight shall then be moved alternately in this fashion from left foot to waist level to right foot; right to waist level to left until it has been moved seven (7) times in each direction with the total horizontal distance of travel being at least twenty-four (24) inches more than the space between the feet for each of the fourteen (14) moves. This shall be done in less than thirty-five (35) seconds. (Code 1976, § 3-603; Ord. No. 81-2, 2-17-81) State Law reference— Firefighter standards and training, OCGA § 25-4-2 et seq. Sec. 6-64. - Same—Duties. It shall be the duty of all firemen to become familiar with and proficient in the handling of all of the apparatus of the fire department, to be prepared at a moment's notice to respond to all alarms of fire, to observe all rules and regulations of the fire department established by the fire chief and to obey all orders of the commanding officer at all fires. (Code 1976, § 3-603; Ord. No. 81-2, 2-17-81) Sec. 6-65. - Daily inspections. Each fire station and its equipment shall be examined daily. Such inspections shall be rigidly made and shall ensure that all apparatus is maintained in excellent working condition at all times, ready for immediate service and that all fire stations and surrounds are in a clean and sanitary condition. (Code 1976, § 3-603) Sec. 6-66. - Firefighting apparatus. (a) Right-of-way of apparatus. The fire department, including its apparatus, when going to any fire in the city or returning therefrom, shall have the right-of-way over the streets, lanes and ways of the city to the exclusion of all persons, vehicles and railroad trains of every kind. (b) Persons permitted on apparatus. No persons other than members of the fire department shall be permitted to ride upon the firefighting apparatus in going to or returning from fires. (c) Obstructing firefighting apparatus. It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct in any manner any firefighting apparatus or any of the officers or members of the fire department in the performance of their duties. (Code 1976, § 3-603) Sec. 6-67. - Command at fires. In case of fire, the officer of the highest rank at the fire shall take command of the fire department and direct the management thereof for the suppression of the fire in the best manner possible. Such commanding officer may cause any building to be removed, torn down or destroyed when such acts are necessary for the protection of other property and for the prevention of the spread of the conflagration. (Code 1976, § 3-603) Sec. 6-68. - Persons permitted within vicinity of fire. No persons other than firemen, city officials, police officers and the property owner or his agent shall be allowed within the immediate vicinity of a fire, unless such persons are given permission to do so by the fire chief. (Code 1976, § 3-603) Sec. 6-69. - Obstructing fire plugs. It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any fire plug so as to obstruct approaches to the same by the fire department. (Code 1976, § 3-603) Sec. 6-70. - False alarm. It shall be unlawful for any person to make, give, send or turn in, in any manner or way whatsoever, a false fire alarm or riot alarm, knowing the same to be false. (Code 1976, § 3-603) Cross reference— False alarms generally, § 10-10. Sec. 6-71. - Use of equipment outside city limits. Upon the orders of the fire chief or the mayor, members of the fire department are authorized to go outside the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of extinguishing fires, rendering aid to other fire departments or for rendering aid in the case of accidents. (Code 1976, § 3-603) ARTICLE V. - LIFE SAFETY CODE
Sec. 6-72. - Adopted. There is hereby adopted by the mayor and city council, for the purpose of prescribing regulations setting life safety standards for those buildings that do not fall under state jurisdiction pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 25-2-13, that certain code known as the Life Safety Code, NFPA 101, 2006 edition, and as thereafter amended or revised as promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association, of which code not less than one (1) copy has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk. The same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. No. 2007-15, § 1, 5-15-07) Sec. 6-73. - Amendments. The Life Safety Code, as enforced by the city of Union City, is hereby amended as follows: (a) By deleting Section 36.1.4.2.4 from Chapter 36 in its entirety, and by replacing it with a new Section 36.1.4.2.4 to be read as follows: 36.1.4.2.4 Where a number of tenant spaces under the same or different management are located in the same building, the aggregate gross area (see 36.1.4.2.2) of all such tenant spaces shall be used in determining classification per 36.1.4.2.1. (b) By deleting Section 36.3.3.2 from Chapter 36 in its entirety, and by replacing it with a new Section 36.3.3.2 to be read as follows: 36.3.3.2 Interior Wall and Ceiling Finish. Interior wall and ceiling finish complying with 10.2.3 shall be Class A or Class B. (c) By deleting Section 36.3.7 from Chapter 36 in its entirety, and by replacing it with a new Section 36.3.7 to be read as follows: 36.3.7 Subdivision of Building Spaces. In all buildings that have multiple tenants it is required that each tenant space be separated by an approved fire barrier to limit the spread of fire or smoke to other spaces to include walls and ceilings. Exception No. 1: If the walls extend from floor to underside of roof deck and are properly sealed, ceiling assembly will not be required. Exception No. 2: If multiple tenants are separated in a building that is classified as a Class A mercantile occupancy as defined in 36.1.4.2.1 of the current adopted Code all sprinkler requirements will apply as outlined in Chapter 37. Exception No. 3: If the building is provided with a smoke control system the front section of each tenant space can be opened as outlined as a covered mall building as defined in 36.4.4. The covered mall and all buildings connected thereto shall be protected throughout by an approved, supervised automatic sprinkler system in accordance with section 9.7. (d) By adding Item 5 in Subsection 2 of Section 36.4.4.8, to be read as follows: (5) Kiosks as defined in 36.4.4.8 cannot exceed 4% of total gross area of a building. (e) By deleting Section 37.1.4.2.4 from Chapter 37 in its entirety, and by replacing it with a new Section 37.1.4.2.4 to be read as follows: 37.1.4.2.4 Where a number of tenant spaces under the same or different management are located in the same building, the aggregate gross area (see 37.1.4.2.2) of all such tenant spaces shall be used in determining classification per 37.1.4.2.1. (f) By deleting Section 37.3.3.2 from Chapter 37 in its entirety, and by replacing it with a new Section 37.3.3.2 to be read as follows: 37.3.3.2 Interior Wall and Ceiling Finish. Interior wall and ceiling finish complying with 10.2.3 shall be Class A or Class B. (g) By deleting Section 37.3.7 from Chapter 37 in its entirety, and by replacing it with a new Section 37.3.7 to be read as follows: 37.3.7 Subdivision of Building Spaces. In all buildings that have multiple tenants it is required that each tenant space be separated by an approved fire barrier to limit the spread of fire or smoke to other spaces to include walls and ceilings. Exception No. 1: If the walls extend from floor to underside of roof deck and are properly sealed, ceiling assembly will not be required. Exception No. 2: If multiple tenants are separated in a building that is classified as a Class A mercantile occupancy as defined in 37.1.4.2.1 of the current adopted Code all sprinkler requirements will apply as outlined in Chapter 37. Exception No. 3: If the building is provided with a smoke control system the front section of each tenant space can be opened as outlined as a covered mall building as defined in 37.4.4. The covered mall and all buildings connected thereto shall be protected throughout by an approved, supervised automatic sprinkler system in accordance with section 9.7. (h) By adding Item 5 in Subsection 2 of Section 37.4.4.8, to be read as follows: (5) Kiosks as defined in 37.4.4.8 cannot exceed 4% of total gross area of a building. (Ord. No. 2007-15, § 1, 5-15-07) Secs. 6-74—6-89. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - FIRE SERVICE FEES
Sec. 6-90. - Assessment and imposition of fees. The city is hereby authorized to impose fees according to a schedule adopted by the mayor and council for services provided by the fire department to insurance companies whose insured are non-residents of the city, are involved in a motor vehicle collision in the city, and determined to be at fault where: (1) The coverage for such services is expressly provided by an insurance company to the non-resident insured and the services are lawfully billed to that insured; or (2) Emergency medical services are provided to the non-resident insured by the city's fire department, whenever the insured's medical insurance covers the services provided and the insured assigns the right to collect to the service provider; or (3) Other services are provided to the non-resident insured by the city's fire department which are expressly authorized by state or federal law to be billed to an insurance company. (Ord. No. 2014-06, § 1, 7-15-14) Sec. 6-91. - Administration of cost recovery. (a) The city manager shall institute processes necessary for fire department reporting, municipal court tracking of traffic citations, and finance department direct billing of fees authorized by this article. (b) The city manager may cause the functions and duties required by subsection (a) hereinabove to be provided using any procurement method authorized by this Code or any procurement policy of the city, including a contract with an outside vendor to perform said functions and duties. (Ord. No. 2014-06, § 1, 7-15-14) Sec. 6-92. - No fees charged to residents of city. No fees under this article shall be imposed against any resident of the City of Union City, either with his or her insurance carrier or directly as a responsible party. (Ord. No. 2014-06, § 1, 7-15-14)

div.head: Chapter 7 - GARBAGE, TRASH AND REFUSE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, § 1-102(c)(2); authority to levy and collect garbage, trash and refuse collection service charges, § 1-103(3); authority to provide for the collection and disposal of garbage, trash and refuse, § 1-103(25); authority to levy and collect a garbage, trash and refuse collection and disposal service charge, tax or fee, § 1-103(26); authority to levy and collect a sanitation tax, § 5-102. Cross reference— Health and sanitation, Ch. 8; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 12. State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. 1983, Art. IX, Sec. II, Para. III(a)(2); solid waste handling, disposal, etc., OCGA § 12-8-20 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 7-1. - Purpose. It is declared to be the policy of Union City, Georgia, in furtherance of its responsibility to protect the public health, safety, and well-being of its citizens and to protect and enhance the quality of its environment, to institute and maintain a comprehensive city-wide program for all solid waste management which will assure that solid waste facilities, whether publicly or privately operated, do not adversely affect the health, safety, and well-being of the public and do not degrade the quality of the environment by reason of location, design, method of operation or other means and which, to the extent feasible and practical, makes maximum utilization of the resources contained in solid waste referred to in this chapter as recovered material. It is further declared to be the policy of Union City to educate and encourage generators and handlers of all solid waste to reduce and minimize to the greatest extent possible the amount of solid waste which requires collection, treatment, or disposal through source reduction, reuse, composting, recycling, and other methods to promote markets for and engage in the purchase of goods made from recovered materials and goods which are recyclable. The mayor and council of the City of Union City does hereby ordain and enact into law the following: (Code 1976, § 10-101; Ord. No. 99-20, § 1, 8-17-99) Sec. 7-2. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other nonmanufacturing activities as defined in section 12-8-22(4.1) of O.C.G.A. Disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of solid waste occurs and includes but is not limited to landfilling and solid waste thermal treatment technology facilities as defined in section 12-8-22(8) of O.C.G.A. Industrial solid waste means waste generated by manufacturing or industrial processes or operations. Such waste includes but is not limited to fertilizer, agricultural chemicals, food and food related products and by-products as defined in section 12-8-22(12.1) of O.C.G.A. Inert waste means wastes that will not or are not likely to cause production of leachate of environmental concern. Such wastes are limited to earth and earth-like products, concrete, cured asphalt, rock, bricks, yard trimmings, stumps, limbs, and leaves. This definition excludes industrial and demolition waste not specifically listed above (Section 391-3-4-.06 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management). Litter means discarded materials of every kind as defined in section 16-7-42(1) of O.C.G.A. Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash, and sanitary waste in septic tanks and means solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds; and day use recreation areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste, but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural, or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations as defined in section 12-8-22(18) of O.C.G.A. Open dump means a disposal facility at which solid waste from one or more sources is left to decompose, burn or to otherwise create a threat to human health or the environment as defined in Section 391-3-4-.01(44) of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management. Public or private property means the right of way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; and residential or farm properties, timberlands, or forests, as defined in section 16-7-42(2) of O.C.G.A. Recovered materials means those materials which have known use, reuse, or recycling potential and have been diverted or removed from the solid waste stream for sale, use, reuse or recycling as defined in section 12-8-22(25) of O.C.G.A. Recovered materials processing facility means a facility engaged solely in the storage, processing, and resale or reuse of recovered materials as defined in section 12-8-22(26) of O.C.G.A. Scrap tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose because of wear, damage, or defect as defined in section 12-8-22(31) of O.C.G.A. Scrap tire generator means any person who generates scrap tires as defined in Section 391-3-4-.19(2.i) of the Georgia Rules of Solid Waste Management. Scrap tire carrier means any person engaged in picking up or transporting scrap tires not otherwise exempted under Section 391-3-4-.19(5.g) [of the Georgia Rules of Solid Waste Management] for the purpose of removal to a scrap tire processor, end user, or disposal facility as defined in section 12-8-22(32) of O.C.G.A. Solid waste means any garbage or refuse; sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution contract facility; and other discarded material including solid, liquid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial, mining, and agricultural operations and from community activities, but does not include recovered materials; solid or dissolved materials in domestic sewage; solid or dissolved materials in irrigation return flows or industrial discharges that are point sources subject to permit under 33 U.S.C. Section 1342; or source, special nuclear, or byproduct material as defined by the federal Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended (68 Stat. 923) as defined in section 12-8-22(33) of O.C.G.A. Solid waste handling means the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing or disposal of solid waste, or any combination of such activities as defined in section 12-8-22(34) of O.C.G.A. Tire retailer means any person engaged in the business of selling new replacement tires as defined in section 12-8-22(39) of O.C.G.A. Transfer station means a facility used to transfer solid wastes from one transportation vehicle to another for transportation to a disposal facility. (Code 1976, § 10-102; Ord. No. 92-8, § 1, 8-4-92; Ord. No. 99-20, § 2, 8-17-99) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 7-3. - Enforcement. (a) In general. The superintendent of public works shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter. In the exercise of his solid waste management duties, the superintendent shall: (1) Supervise the collection of solid waste, including the operation and maintenance of equipment and the supervision of personnel; (2) Establish collection schedules in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (b) Limitations of authority. All regulatory actions of the superintendent of public works shall be subject to the review of the mayor and council. (c) Appeal. Any person aggrieved by a requirement of, or a fee charged by, the superintendent of public works shall have the right to appeal to the mayor and council, which body may, upon a hearing, confirm, modify or revoke such requirement or fee. (Code 1976, § 10-103) Sec. 7-4. - Precollection. (a) In general. No person shall keep or store solid waste outside of any residence or building within the city, except in proper containers for collection or otherwise prepared, as set forth in this chapter or under the express prior approval of the director of public works. Any unauthorized accumulation of solid waste is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. The director of public works by written notice shall notify the owner or occupant of any premises with such solid waste accumulation to remove same. Failure to remove such accumulation within two (2) weeks of the date of such written notice to do so shall be deemed a violation of these regulations and subject to penalties set forth in section 7-13. A separate violation shall be deemed committed each day during or upon which such unlawful accumulation continues. (b) Containers. A waste wheeler cart shall be provided by the city to each single-family residence to accommodate solid waste generated by the residents. The safekeeping of the cart shall be the responsibility of the occupant of the residence. The cart shall at all times remain the property of the city. (c) Placement. Waste containers must be placed at the street for the garbage to be collected. Containers shall be placed at the street no sooner than 12:00 noon the day immediately preceding the collection day and must be removed no later than 10:00 a.m. on the day immediately following the collection day unless other arrangements have been made with the superintendent. When waste containers are not placed at the street for collection purposes, they shall be screened from public view. (d) Scavenging. No person other than the owner or authorized collection personnel shall sift the contents of or remove anything from containers, boxes or bundles containing garbage or rubbish. (e) Maintenance of containers. All solid waste or litter containers or receptacles shall be maintained in as sanitary a manner as is reasonably possible consistent with its use for solid waste and litter disposal. (f) Depositing of authorized materials. Persons using solid waste and litter containers or receptacles shall deposit only authorized solid waste and refuse in the container or receptacle. (g) Scrap tires. No person shall deposit a scrap tire in any container or receptacle unless authorized by the owner of the receptacle or the mayor and council or their designee. (h) Burning or smoldering material. No person shall deposit any burning or smoldering material in such container or receptacle. (i) Setting fire to contents. No person shall set fire to the contents of any such container or receptacle. (j) Noncompatible materials. No person shall deposit large noncompatible articles in containers or receptacles such as, but not limited to, stoves, refrigerators, bed springs, large tree limbs or air conditioning units, except containers or receptacles designated for that purpose only. (k) Flammable or explosive materials. No person shall deposit any flammable or explosive materials in any such container or receptacle. (l) Dead animals. No dead animals shall be deposited in any such container or receptacle. (m) Willful damage or altering of location. No person shall willfully damage or alter the location of any such container or receptacle without the written consent of the mayor and council. (n) Salvage or scavenging. No salvage or scavenging operations shall be conducted in or around such containers or receptacles except by written consent of the mayor and council. (o) Depositing at solid waste collection and recycling center. No person shall deposit any solid waste at a city solid waste collection and recycling center unless such solid waste is contained in a manner that it can be handled by the attendant and shall be deposited only during the official hours of operation. (p) Depositing of authorized materials. No person shall deposit solid waste, water or litter of any kind at any city solid waste collection and recycling center into city-owned receptacles or containers designated for the collection of recovered materials. Only authorized materials such as a glass, aluminum, newspaper, cardboard, plastic, and tin or other accepted material may be deposited in the appropriate container designated for said material. (Code 1976, § 10-104; Ord. No. 98-15, § 1, 9-15-98; Ord. No. 99-20, § 5, 8-17-99) Sec. 7-5. - Collection. (a) Frequency. Garbage shall be collected from residential premises once weekly. Garbage shall be collected from commercial and business establishments in accord with need and convenience, as determined by the superintendent. Rubbish shall be collected upon request made to the city. (b) Limitations. Industrial waste, large animals over thirty (30) pounds or waste from construction, demolition, landscaping or processing operations will not be collected, transported or disposed of by public facilities, as all such waste collection, transportation and disposal shall be made by the owners or generators of such waste or animals. (c) Hazardous materials. It shall be a violation of these regulations to place or to cause to be placed in any container, box, bundle or otherwise for collection any hazardous waste of any kind, except upon specific prior arrangement with the director of public works. (d) It shall be unlawful to drive or operate a vehicle in Union City hauling municipal, commercial, or industrial solid waste that leaks, flows freely or spills from said vehicle. (e) Any litter or municipal, commercial, or industrial solid waste hauled on a moving vehicle shall be covered or secured in such a manner that litter will not blow or escape from said vehicle while moving or parked on public or private property in Union City. (Code 1976, § 10-105; Ord. No. 99-20, § 4, 8-17-99) Sec. 7-6. - Waste disposal. (a) The owner or occupant of any premises shall be responsible for the sanitary handling and disposing of all litter, scrap tires, and municipal, commercial or industrial solid waste on the premises used or occupied by such person. (b) It shall be unlawful to dump, open dump, or permit the dumping of litter, scrap tires, municipal, commercial, or industrial solid waste or recyclables at any place in this city including, and without limitations, any public or private property in the city or any waters in this city unless: (1) The property is designated by the mayor and council or its duly designated agent for the disposal of litter, municipal, commercial or industrial solid waste, scrap tires or recovered materials and the person is authorized to use such property. (2) The litter, municipal, commercial or industrial solid waste, recyclables or scrap tires is placed into a receptacle or container installed specifically for such property; or (3) The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property or has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare and not otherwise in violation of law. (4) The property has a valid solid waste handling permit issued by EPD. (c) All persons defined as scrap tire generators, scrap tire carriers, tire retailers shall be subject to rules as defined in section 391-3-4-.19 [of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management,] and handle scrap tires in accordance with the provisions of section 12-8-20 et seq. of O.C.G.A. and the Rules for Solid Waste Management, Chapter 391-3-4 applicable to solid waste. (Code 1976, § 10-106; Ord. No. 99-20, § 3, 8-17-99) Sec. 7-7. - Garbage removal tax. (a) Levy. A monthly garbage removal tax is hereby levied and assessed against all of the different classes of persons, and against all of the various classes, kinds and sizes of improved building lots of land and improvements thereon to be served or benefited by the city's removal of garbage therefrom, and against the owner or owners thereof, and against each and all of the occupants and tenants thereof, and against each water customer of the city, and against the head of each family within the city; provided, however, that the maximum monthly garbage removal tax shall be eleven dollars and twenty-five cents ($11.25), and provided further, that a building lot shall consist of any lot of land with a building thereon, and no building lot shall be considered improved unless there is a building thereon. For collection of such garbage removal tax, the city shall have a lien against such building lot and improvements thereon, and the owner thereof, which are delinquent in payment, which lien shall be prior and superior to any and all other liens except state and county tax liens, and except that it shall be equal to any liens said city may have against such building lot for city taxes. (b) Amount. The amount of tax or charge for removal of garbage from a residence is hereby fixed at eleven dollars and twenty-five cents ($11.25) per month. The amount of tax or charge for removal of garbage from a lot with a business, commercial, professional, institutional building, or factory thereon, shall be twelve dollars and five cents ($12.05) per cubic yard provided the minimum charge per month for garbage removal services from business establishments shall not be less than twenty-four dollars and ten cents ($24.10) whether the amount removed is more or less than one (1) cubic yard. (c) Payment. The garbage removal service charge shall be due and payable by each person liable therefor at the same time that water bills are due and payable on the premises. If the premises are not served by water, the bill shall be payable by the fifteenth of the month for the previous month's service. (d) Water/sewer and garbage removal tax penalty. If payment for water service, sewer service, and/or the garbage removal tax is not made on or before the due date stated on the applicable bill rendered (said due dates fall on either the first or the fifteenth of each month), an additional service charge of ten (10) percent of the outstanding debt shall be added to the amount due. (Ord. No. 87-9, §§ 1—3, 2-3-87; Ord.No. 00-10, § 10-107, 9-9-00; Ord. No. 2004-03, § 1, 3-16-04; Ord. No. 2004-16, § 1, 8-17-04) Cross reference— Taxation and finance, Ch. 13. Sec. 7-8. - Extra trash pickup. The amount of tax or charge for removal of extra trash from a residential lot shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such charges is on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. No. 83-4, 3-15-83) Sec. 7-9. - Dumpsters. The amount of tax or charge for a change out of dumpster sizes at a customer's request from a lot with a business, commercial, professional, institutional building or factory thereon shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such charges is on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. No. 83-4, 3-15-83) Sec. 7-10. - Franchises. (a) Authority. The mayor and council shall have the authority to grant the right, privilege and franchise to remove and dispose of solid waste within all zoning districts. The franchise, authority or permit granted shall extend for a period not to exceed three (3) calendar years. (b) Fees. The grantee of a franchise to remove and dispose of solid waste shall pay to the city a fee in the amount of ten (10) percent of the total monthly billing collected. This fee shall be paid on or before the fifteenth day of each month for the collection of solid waste the preceding month. If the franchise fee shall be in arrears in whole or in part for fifteen (15) or more days, the mayor and council shall have the option to cancel the franchise. (c) Records. All books and records of a grantee concerning its operations within the city and the collection of bills shall be made available for inspection and audit by the administrative officer or his designee within thirty (30) days after any request for such inspection or audit. (Ord. No. 80-5, 4-15-80) Charter reference— Authority to grant franchises for public services, § 1-103(10). Cross reference— Public utility franchise tax, § 13-2. Sec. 7-11. - Records and reports. (a) All contractors and private vendors providing solid waste handling services within the city shall keep records relevant to the provision of such services. All required information shall be carefully documented by the service provider, and shall be reported to the city on a monthly basis. Required information which shall be compiled and reported to the city includes the following: (1) Amount of solid waste collected in tons. (2) Origin of solid waste collected. (3) Type of solid waste collected. (4) Disposal site location and tipping fee. (5) Number of customers served by collection service. (6) Types of solid waste handling services provided. (7) Recycling quantities and materials recycled from private organizations. (8) Amount of solid waste recycled in tons. (9) Amount of solid waste landfilled in tons. (b) Failure to compile such information and to provide the city with such reports on the dates due, as scheduled by the city administrator, shall constitute a violation of the Code of Ordinances, and shall subject such violator to a penalty up to, but no more than, the maximum fine and/or jail term allowed in the city court. For purposes of this section, each week beyond the scheduled due date in which the service provider continues to withhold the necessary information from the city shall constitute a separate violation. (Ord. No. 92-8, § 2, 8-4-92) Sec. 7-12. - Regulation of landfills, solid waste collection and recycling centers. (a) No landfill shall be operated in Union City, Georgia, other than a landfill designated by the mayor and council as the city landfill, and no private municipal solid waste landfill shall be operated in Union City, Georgia, without a solid waste handling permit issued by the Georgia Environmental Protection Division. (b) No person shall deposit solid waste of any kind outside the gate of a solid waste collection and recycling center. (c) No scavenging operation of any kind shall be allowed at a solid waste collection and recycling center. (d) No person shall move, remove, or cross any fence, gate, barrier, or sign at a solid waste collection recycling center. (e) Price on solid waste brought to said center will be set to defray total cost of solid waste and recycling operations. (f) Hours of operation of said centers will be set to maximize convenient use of residents of that area. (g) All recovered materials (recyclables) brought to collection centers will be accepted free of charge, provided, it is separated under current market specifications and likewise uncontaminated. (h) Attendant on duty will have full authority of said center consistent with this chapter. (i) All rules listed above shall apply to all public and/or private property in said city, all waters and/or waterways of said city, and all city solid waste collection and recycling centers. (Ord. No. 99-20, § 6, 8-17-99) Sec. 7-13. - Violation. Any person violating any portion of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or punishment within the sound discretion of the Judge of the Municipal Court of Union City. The offender(s) may also be directed to pickup and remove litter from public or private areas as provided in section 16-7-43(b) of O.C.G.A. (Ord. No. 99-20, § 7, 8-17-99) Secs. 7-14—7-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RECYCLING
Sec. 7-21. - Separation of recyclable trash for curbside pickup. (a) Newspapers; (b) Aluminum cans and aluminum products (which shall have been emptied of all contents, both liquid and solid); (c) Glass products (which shall have been emptied of all contents, both liquid and solid); and (d) Plastics (which shall have been emptied of all contents, both liquid and solid). (1) For the purpose of this article, condominium units and fee-simple townhomes will be treated like single-family residences, and multifamily dwelling complexes shall mean those complexes consisting of more than one (1) single-family dwelling unit under one (1) ownership. (2) All residents of multifamily complexes and condominium units shall separate the above-listed recyclable items of trash for placement into a designated container, which shall be located in an area established by the multifamily complex owner or the condominium complex manager as the pickup area. (3) Residents of Union City who fail to separate recyclable trash and/or garbage from other trash and/or garbage shall be fined a penalty of no more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) in the Municipal Court of Union City, for failing to comply with the terms and conditions of this ordinance. (4) Current fee schedules and pickup schedules will be kept on file in city hall, and are subject to change at the discretion of the city.

div.head: Chapter 8 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to provide for public health services, § 1-102(c)(3); authority to prescribe health standards, § 1-103(21); authority to regulate and prohibit any act etc., detrimental to the health and sanitation of the inhabitants of the city, § 1-103(29); authority to abate nuisances, § 1-103(30); authority to regulate the emission and disposal of any substance that tends to pollute land, water or air, § 1-103(47). Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; garbage, and trash and refuse, Ch. 7. State Law reference— Heath, OCGA Title 31.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 8-1. - Care of premises—Required; notice to remove rubbish, etc. (a) It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of a residential or commercial building, structure or property to utilize, use or permit the use of the premises of such residential or commercial property for the open storage of any abandoned motor vehicle, ice box, refrigerator, stove, glass, building material, building rubbish or similar items. It shall be the duty and responsibility of every such owner or occupant to keep the premises of such residential or commercial property clean and to remove from the premises all such abandoned items as listed above, including but not limited to weeds, dead trees, excessively tall grass, trash, rubbish, garbage, etc., upon notice from the city clerk or premises inspector. Specifically excluded from this section are those disposal facilities or sites as defined in Chapter 7 of the Union City Code of Ordinances and regulated in accordance with such chapter and state laws, and the business premises of those junk dealers holding current and valid licenses issued pursuant to section 9-25 of the Union City Code of Ordinances. (b) For the purpose of this section, an abandoned motor vehicle is defined as one that is in a state of disrepair and incapable of being moved under its own power. (c) It shall be the duty and responsibility of every such owner or occupant to keep the premises of such property clean and to remove from the premises all such items as listed in subsection (a) above upon notice from the city clerk or premises inspector. The notice shall be in writing and shall set forth the hazard to be removed. This notice shall require the owner or occupant to remove the hazard within seven (7) days or, if the hazard set forth in the notice is the first such offense during a period of twelve (12) consecutive months, the owner or occupant may file an appeal in writing to the mayor and council of the city. If the occupant is not the owner of record, according to the city tax returns, a copy of the notice shall be delivered or mailed to the owner. (d) Should the owner or occupant, after notice, fail to remove the hazard as complained, it shall be the duty of the city clerk or premises inspector to cause the same to be removed by the use of city equipment and employees. If the city does not have sufficient equipment and/or employees to perform the removal, the city clerk or premises inspector, with the approval of the mayor and council of the city may contract with outside forces for the removal of the hazard. The total cost to the city for removing the hazard shall be a special lien against the property, placed upon the tax records of the city and subject to foreclosure. (e) Should the owner or occupant give cause to receive notice for more than one (1) offense for the same violation during a period of twelve (12) consecutive months, the city clerk or premises inspector shall issue a citation to the owner or occupant to appear before the city court and there shall be no appeal to the mayor and council of the city for the second or subsequent offense occurring during a period of twelve (12) consecutive months. (Ord. No. 83-2, 4-5-83; Ord. No. 93-6, 7-20-93) Sec. 8-2. - Same—Appeal; authority, duty of mayor and council; right of aggrieved party. (a) Hearing; time; conduct. The mayor and council of the city shall normally hold hearings on appeals filed pursuant to section 8-1 within thirty (30) days after they are filed. The mayor and council, when so appealed to and after a public hearing, may vary the application of any provision of section 8-1 to any particular case when, in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would be manifest injustice, and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of this chapter or the public interest, or when, in its opinion, the interpretations of the city clerk or premises inspector should be modified or renewed. (b) Decision. The decision of the mayor and council to vary the application of any provision of this section or to modify an order of the city clerk or premises inspector, shall specify in what manner such variation or modification is made, the conditions upon which it is made, and reasons therefor. Every decision shall be a public record and a certified copy thereof shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant. (c) Effect of appeal. An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from until a decision thereon shall have been made by the mayor and council. (d) Application for court relief. A person aggrieved by a decision of the mayor and council of the city, whether previously a party to the proceeding or not, may within fifteen (15) days after the rendition of the decision apply to the appropriate court for any relief afforded by the laws of the state. (e) Duty of building official. If the decision of the mayor and council reverses or modifies a refusal or disallowance of the city clerk or premises inspector, or various application of this chapter, the city clerk or premises inspector shall take action in accordance with such decision. (Ord. No. 83-2, 4-5-83) Sec. 8-3. - Premises inspector designated. There shall be a premises inspector who shall have the authority to perform the functions required by sections 8-1 and 8-2 or by resolution of the mayor and council. The premises inspector shall be responsible for making an inspection of the premises at the direction of the city clerk or the mayor and council of the city. (Ord. No. 83-2, 4-5-83) Sec. 8-4. - Nuisances. (a) Defined. A "nuisance" in general terms shall be construed to mean anything that causes hurt, inconvenience or damage to another, and the fact that the act done may otherwise be legal does not keep it from being a nuisance. The consequences complained of must not be fanciful or such as would only affect a person of fastidious tastes, but it must be such as would affect an ordinary, reasonable person. "Nuisance" as defined in this section shall be in addition to any and all other definitions of nuisances contained in the ordinances of the city. (b) Authority to abate. The city court shall have full power to order the abatement of any nuisance, whether public or private, within the city, and the chief of police or other police officers of the city, or the sheriff of the county or his deputies, shall have full power and authority to execute the court's order. (c) Complaint, notice of hearing. When any nuisance exists in the city, any person affected thereby may apply or complain to the city court or the chief of police for abatement thereof, and it shall be the duty of the court or of the chief of police to cause reasonable notice of not less than four (4) days, to the parties interested, of the time and place of hearing. The complaint shall be in writing, shall specify the acts or thing complained of, and shall be signed by the person or persons seeking the abatement. Notice of the hearing shall be in writing, shall be served upon the parties interested by the police department, and shall reasonably specify the nuisance sought to be abated. The service may be personal or may be accomplished by leaving the notice at the residences of the parties interested. (d) Order to abate; execution for costs. When any person shall be convicted of creating or maintaining a nuisance, he shall be ordered to abate such nuisance within a reasonable time to be fixed by the court, and should such person fail or refuse to abide by the court's order, it shall be the duty of the chief of police and the other police officers of the city to abate the same at the cost of the defendant. In any instance of failure or refusal to abate a nuisance after ordered to do so by the city court, and the abatement thereof by the police department, the cost thereof shall be collected by execution, levy and sale as in cases of taxes due the city. (e) Issuance of execution. The execution provided for in subsection (d) above shall be issued by the city clerk when the chief of police shall make affidavit stating the reasonable cost of abating the nuisance, and the execution shall issue for the reasonable cost or expense as shown by such affidavit. (Code 1976, §§ 8-101—8-105) State Law reference— Authorization and procedure for abatement of nuisances in cities, OCGA § 41-2-5. Secs. 8-5—8-15. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - AIR POLLUTION CONTROL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Authority to control air pollution, § 1-102(c)(14); authority to regulate smoke and air pollution, § 1-103(22). State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide air quality control, Ga. Const. 1983, Art. IX, Sec. II, Para. III(a)(13).
Sec. 8-16. - Title. This article shall be known and cited as the "Union City Air Pollution Control Ordinance." (Code 1976, § 11-101) Sec. 8-17. - Authority. In agreement with the federal Air Quality Act of 1967 (P.L. 90-148) and with the state air quality control law and by the authority vested in the county commissioners of roads and revenues by the General Assembly of Georgia (Ga. Laws 1953, p. 2718) pursuant to constitutional amendment (Ga. Laws 1951, p. 828) this article is hereby established. (Code 1976, § 11-102) Sec. 8-18. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to provide minimum standards or ordinances to safeguard life, health, property and public welfare of the citizens of this city and others from the effects of air pollution and air contamination. (Code 1976, § 11-103) Sec. 8-19. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Air contaminant means any solid particulate matter, gas, liquid, vapor or combination thereof not naturally present in the atmosphere. Air pollution means the presence in the outdoor atmosphere of one (1) or more air contaminants to an extent which injures or tends to injure human health or well-being, animal or plant life or health or property, or which impairs visibility or safety, or which interferes with the reasonable use and enjoyment of life and property. Approved means meeting the requirements of the health officer. Chimney means a vertical masonry or concrete shaft enclosing one (1) or more flues. Department means the county health department. Dust means solid particles released into or carried in the air by natural forces, or by any fuel-burning, combustion, or other equipment or device, construction work or by mechanical or industrial process. Excess air means air entering a combustion chamber in excess of the amount theoretically required for complete combustion of materials in the combustion chamber. Flue means a vertical passageway for the purpose of removing products of combustion from solid, liquid or gas fuel. Fly ash means particulate matter capable of being gas-borne or air-borne and consisting essentially of fused and/or other burned or unburned materials resulting from combustion of fuel or refuse. Fuel-burning equipment means any equipment, device or contrivance for burning any fuel except refuse and all appurtenances thereto, which is used for indirect heating and in which the material being heated is not contacted by, and adds no substance to, the products of combustion. Such equipment typically includes that used for heating water, generating or superheating steam, heating air as in warm air furnaces, furnishing process heat indirectly through transfer by fluids or transmission through process vessel walls. Hand-fired fuel-burning equipment means fuel-burning equipment in which fresh fuel is manually introduced directly into the combustion chamber. Health officer means the county commissioner of health, or his authorized representative. Incinerator (See refuse-burning equipment). Internal combustion engine means any engine in which the combustion of gaseous, liquid or pulverized solid fuel takes place within one (1) or more cylinders. Multiple-chamber incinerator means any article, machine, equipment or contrivance which is used for disposal of refuse by burning and which consists of a series of three (3) or more combustion chambers physically separated by refractory walls, interconnected by gas passages or ducts, and lined with refractories having a pyrometric cone equivalent of at least 17, tested according to ASTM method C-24, and is designed for efficient combustion of the type and volume of material to be burned. Objectionable odor means an odor deemed objectionable by the health officer and at least twenty-five (25) percent of the people exposed to it, if there are at least twenty (20) people so exposed, or at least five (5) people if there are fewer than twenty (20) people exposed. Open burning means any outdoor fire from which the products of combustion are emitted directly into the open air without passing through a flue. Particulate matter means material other than water which is suspended in air or other gases, in a finely divided form, as a liquid or solid. Process equipment means any equipment, device or contrivance for mixing, changing, storing or handling any material, the use or existence of which may cause any discharge of air contaminants into the open air, but excluding that equipment defined in this section as "fuel-burning equipment" or "refuse-burning equipment." Refuse means waste, garbage, rubbish, trash or any combination thereof. Refuse-burning equipment means any equipment, device or contrivance used for the destruction and/or reduction of rubbish or other wastes by burning, and all appurtenances thereto. Ringelmann Smoke Chart means the chart published and described in the U.S. Bureau of Mines Information Circular 7718 for use in measuring the shades, density or opacity of air contaminants arising from stacks and other sources, and being on file in the office of the clerk of the county commissioners of roads and revenues. The miniature Ringelmann charts are a derivative of the above in common use. Rubbish means tree branches, twigs, grass, shrub clippings, weeds, leaves and/or street sweepings, waste paper, cardboard and combustible containers. Smoke means small gas-borne or air-borne particles resulting from combustion operations and industrial processes and consisting of carbon and ash or other matter and present in sufficient quantity to be visible. Smokestack means a vertical flue constructed of metal. (Code 1976, § 11-104) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 8-20. - Visible emissions. (a) No person shall cause, allow or permit visible emissions into the open air from any source of an opacity, shade or appearance equal to or darker than number two (2) of the Ringelmann Smoke Chart. The use of miniature Ringelmann charts to determine compliance with this article is authorized. (b) Exceptions to subsection (a) above are: (1) Visible emissions consisting of uncombined water droplets; (2) Smoke emitted during the cleaning of a fire, the building of a new fire or the blowing of soot from boiler surfaces, the shade or appearance of which is not darker than number three (3) of the Ringelmann Smoke Chart for a period or periods aggregating no more than three (3) minutes in any thirty (30) consecutive minutes; (3) Batch-type, high-temperature industrial processes during charging and discharging for which no practical means have been devised for collection of emissions therefrom; (4) Smoke resulting from any fire ignited for the purpose of training firemen or for research in fire protection or prevention; (5) Smoke resulting temporarily and briefly from an unavoidable breakdown or malfunction of equipment, provided that nothing in this section shall be construed to permit the continued operation of equipment subject to repeated breakdown or chronic malfunction, or of equipment so obsolete or worn as to require frequent repairs or to preclude dependable and efficient operation. The department shall be notified when breakdowns of equipment cause smoking for thirty (30) minutes or longer, by the owner or his agent. (Code 1976, § 11-105) Sec. 8-21. - Hand-fired fuel-burning equipment. (a) It shall be unlawful to operate any hand-fired fuel-burning equipment. (b) Exception to subsection (a) above involves fuel-burning equipment of a capacity less than that needed for heating a dwelling of fewer than three (3) families. (c) Where the health officer finds that the cost of complying with subsection (a) above in regard to specific installations is not commensurate with the benefit to be derived by the public, the health officer may, upon written request, grant an extension of time for compliance. Such extension shall expire in not more than one (1) year but may, at the discretion of the health officer, be further extended upon a new showing of the justification for such extension. (Code 1976, § 11-106) Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6. Sec. 8-22. - Smoke alarms, indicators, recorders, and remote observation devices. (a) When the top of a flue connected to any fuel-burning or refuse-burning equipment is not readily visible to the person operating such equipment, provision shall be made for use of mirrors or other devices to permit the person operating such equipment to readily determine the opacity or character of the flue discharge. (b) Exceptions to subsection (a) involves gas-fired fuel-burning equipment, fuel-burning equipment fired with number one (1) or two (2) fuel oil and fuel-burning equipment used exclusively for heating a dwelling of fewer than three (3) families. (c) Whenever three (3) or more violations of section 8-20 occur within any thirty-day period, the health officer may require that an automatic recording smoke emission indicator and alarm be installed on such equipment. However, this provision shall not apply to installations used exclusively for heating a dwelling of fewer than three (3) families. (Code 1976, § 11-107) Sec. 8-23. - Open burning. (a) No open burning shall be allowed on any premises except for the cooking of food for immediate human consumption; comfort heating with equipment approved by the health officer, subject to the provisions of section 8-20; and burning of rubbish in areas where public or commercial collection services are not available. (b) Materials such as asphaltic materials, plastic materials, rubber materials, gasolines or oils, or any other material producing dense smoke or obnoxious odors shall not be used for starting or maintaining an open fire. (c) Beginning January 1, 1996, all open burning shall be prohibited during the months of May, June, July, August, and September. The only exceptions to this general prohibition against open burning during the months of May, June, July, August and September shall be: (1) For the recreational purpose of cooking food for human consumption; (2) Fires set for the purpose of training fire fighting personnel when authorized by the director of public safety; (3) Operation devises using open flames such as tar kettles, blow torches, welding torches, portable heaters, and other flame-making equipment where approved safety measures are used; and (4) Setting and maintenance by contractors and tradesmen of miscellaneous small warming fires for their workers. (Code 1976, § 11-108; Ord. No. 96-4, § 1, 5-21-96) Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6. Sec. 8-24. - Incinerators. (a) No person shall construct a new incinerator within this city unless: (1) It is a multiple-chamber incinerator with sufficient combustion volume for its rated capacity and type of material to be burned; (2) It is provided with an auxiliary burner for the purposes of creating preignition temperatures; (3) It has an efficient gas washer of the venturi or impingement type with at least three (3) wet impingement surfaces; (4) It has an adequate and approved induced draft fan; (5) It has a secondary burner for use when necessary to destroy smoke or odors. (b) Incinerators of a design capacity of more than fifty (50) tons per twenty-four (24) hours may be exempt from the provisions of subsection (a) of this section at the discretion of the health officer, provided that all other incinerator standards are met. (c) No person shall make major alterations or repairs to an incinerator which will cost more than thirty (30) percent of the replacement cost of the incinerator, unless such major alterations or repairs will result in a final installation meeting the requirements of subsection (a) of this section. Any incinerator alteration or repair work costing more than fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be approved by the health officer prior to such alteration or repair. The owner shall be responsible for submitting such engineering data to the health officer as required to make clear the extent of the proposed alterations or repairs. (d) No person shall install or construct an incinerator to be used for the disposal of combustible waste from fewer than fifty-one (51) families. (e) Incinerators shall be maintained in good working order and shall be operated so as to: (1) Maintain a temperature of at least eight hundred (800) degrees Fahrenheit in the primary combustion chamber; (2) Comply with generally recognized good practices and all applicable provisions of this article; (3) Make full and proper use of all components and appurtenances thereof.
